Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:The sanctions against the school were a punishing blow, and they seemed to what the efforts the school had made to change? Choices:  A: ignore B: enforce C: authoritarian D: yell at E: avoid<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Incorrect<n><n>The sanctions against the student were a punishing blow and they seemed to undermine the efforts the school had been making to make a positive change.<n><n>Correct<n>The sanctions against what the student had been making to make change seemed to undermine a punishing blow.<n><n>Incorrect<n>The sanctions against The student were a punishing what seemed to undermine what The student had made to make change.<n><n>Incorrect The sanctions against the student seemed to undermine student who made a great change.<n><n>### Input<n><n>Choose a number from 1 to 5 to fill in the blank. <n><n>There are fewer than ___ 5 people from that town. <n><n>### Response<n><n>Incorrect<n>There is fewer than 5 people<n><n>Correct<n>There is less than 5 people.<n><n>Incorrect There is fewer than 5 animals.<n><n>Incorrect More than 5 animals are in this group.<n><n>Incorrect At this party, there are less people.<n><n>Incomplete<n>There are less than 5 people, but there are at least ___. (1,2,3,4)<n><n>Incorrect Less than 5<n><n>### Input The student had worked out a special formula for calculating the average temperature of the planet if the sun shined and the time of day. If the average temperature was 250 degrees in the morning and 300 degrees in the afternoon, the student's formula determined that the temperature would equal 275 degrees in the evening. Is this correct? Choices: A: yes, he is right B: yes, he is wrong C: no, he is wrong D: no, he is right<n><n>### Response Yes, He is right<n><n>The formula that calculates the temperature of the planet if it is shining and the time of day is equal to the sum of two equal sized units, when multiplied by the factor of 275 divided by the number of values.<n><n>### Incorrect
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:The fox walked from the city into the forest, what was it looking for? Choices:  A: pretty flowers. B: hen house C: natural habitat D: storybook E: dense forest<n><n>### Response:		<n>If it was the fox we would say it was looking for a storybook in that forest, not sure what else it might be looking for.<n><n>### Input<n>A person is looking for a job, and the recruiter is looking for somebody who has a great experience of Java Programming, how many people have such experience?<n><n>### Response<n>In order to determine this we would ask the recruitor how many people he has interviewed so far and ask that person if they have experience of Java and if they know any people with experience of java if so what is there name and what job they are doing.<n>We could then use the number the recruiter has interviwed and the list we have and count the number of people who have experience in java.<n><n>### Question:<n>Evan is preparing to enter a long-distance race. He needs to complete his endurance workouts first.<n>He wants to split up his long-distance run by running three miles, then stopping to walk briefly, running another 8 miles, and then walking a good distance.<n>Once he has completed the endurance training, Evan then needs to do strength training before the race.<n>Evan would like to do a 2-mile bike ride, 2-lap swim, then lift weights and do stretches to be physically fit for the race.<n>What is the sum of the distances Evan will run that he will be doing two of?<n><n>### Answer:<n>The sum of the distances Evoan will run that he will do 2 of is 10 miles.<n><n>### Task:<n>In a country fair, Jill saw 8 kids and 14 adults who came to petition a local issue. The total number of people that came to support the cause was 37, how did you figure that?<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Follow these instructions to solve this challenge.<n><n>* 20 people supported the issue first, and 10 people left.<n>* Then 33 people came to petition, and 12 people left.<n>* How many people left after the 12 people?<n>* Then 9 more people came and 3 more left.<n>* How more people were left?<n><n>### Solve:<n>The correct sum is the 20 people supported, plus the 32

Shirt pocket<n><n>### Input<n>> I wonder how much money he will have after paying his debts.<n><n>### Response<n>> About 200 dollars.<n><n>### Input**: Write a description that includes the following: 1. The type of object that you want to sort. 2. The criteria of the sorting (color, size, shape).<n>### Response<n><n>### Input1:**: How much money will she need to buy both?<n><n>Answer: 1.87USD(= 187 yen), because total amount of money needed is 1.34 USD and the amount of money has to be rounded (300 yen + 300 yen+.67 yen = 0.979 yen), so 0.97 is rounded as 1.<n><n>### I1:**: If she has saved up 200 yen(400 yen to buy the toy), she'll still need to buy the toy at the cost of 200 yens.<n><n>Answer: yes, she'll need to buy it at the cost of 700yen(= 500yen * 2).<n><n>### I2:**: How long did it take her to save for her purchase?<n><n>Answer: yes - she'll need to save 1150 yen to purchase, because the cost of toy=499.<n><n>### E1:**: 48.<n>### E2:**: 11, because 47 + 45 =46. But 45 + 45 = 90.<n>### E3:**: 8 - 6.<n>### E4:**: 16, because 11 + 6 = 17.<n>### E5:**: 5, because 1 - 2 + 2 = 5.<n><n>### Exercise21:**: 17, because 16 + 1 = 17. <n>

Where is he? Choices:  A: state park B: bus depot C: garden D: gym E: rest area<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>Input: John has $15 in one bank and $25 in another bank.  How much money does he have?<n><n>### Response:-48<n><n>Input: There are a total of 60 tiles in the floor of a certain room, if there is no duplicate tile they want to tile the room with 3 tiles and they want the left hand border to be tile 1. if they tile the room with tiles 2 and 3 and tile 3 is the tile to the right-most of the left hand border, what is the smallest left hand border tile that can tile a certain room?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: left-most of the left-hand border = 2<n>So: 2 = 2*[floor(2+3/2) - 1]<n><n>### Response :3<n><n>Input: There is a rectangular sheet which we know has an area of 40,000 square inches. if we cut this rectangle in half across the diagonal which divides the rectangle in half then both cuts have an area of 20,000 sq inches, how do you calculate the length of the diagonal if we only know the area of both the entire rectangle, first half, and the after half and have to know the diagonal of the rectangular sheet to fill in the missing information.<n><n>### Response in text:<n>> We don't know the exact length, but we know if it's x, area before cutting = area after cutting = 20000<n>>areaBefore=40000*x/2<n>>areaAfter=4000*x<n>><n>>x = (10000*4)/(4000-20000)<n>><n>>x=49.5<n><n>Input: How many seconds are in 3 days?<n><n>### Answer: 13339<n><n>Input: Alice's father is 5 times as old as Alice.  If 19 years ago, her father was 48 years old, how old is Alice?<n><n>### Deomstratons:<n>Input: 5 times as old means 5*48, let x = the difference between the age of their both, 5x-48 = 5*4

Choices:  A: excitement B: fatigue C: anger D: hurting E: getting tired<n><n>### Response:		Explanation of your code. What was the most difficult part of the task? What did you learn from this task?<n><n>input: A<n><n>### Why?<n>The task is A. Because they are playing for long time for example the player gets angry if his team gets a loss.<n><n>### input: B<n><n>```scala<n>val answer = "A"<n>```<n><n>### Why:<n>The task is B. Because they're getting hurt and angry if their team is a loser.<n><n>### Input C<n>```scala<n>val numberOfYears = 5<n>val answer = "E"<n>```<n><n>Why: The input task is A and the answer is E because if you play for a long time it results in getting tired and you need to rest to get some energy.<n><n>### Choice D<n>```scala<n>val lengthOfTimeToHurt = 3<n>val answer = "D"<n>```<n><n>Explanation of your code:<n>It is input choice E but I was sure about the input question,so I made the value as false and then I asked the program to print the answer which was "D"<n><n>### Why You Didn't Choose Choice A<n>Choices A is exciting because they win and they get a reward which they celebrate, but in real life they get emotional to the ups and downs of the game, they get happy when they win and they get angry when they lose, they get angry when they don't get rewards they think they deserve for playing well, they start fighting each other and that leads to arguments.<n><n>### Why Choice C<n>When the input choice is a they don't care much but when they win they get happy, when they lose they get angry and those ups and down during the game distracts the team to give its all, then each player starts to fight the opponents and those fights end in arguments and that ends in bad performance for the rest of the game.<n><n><n>### Why Your Choice was incorrect<n>I got this question wrong because even after writing the code twice the program did not tell me that I was getting false in the line if(!answer){<n><n>### What did you learn from the task?<n>In this program I learned that the value in line 2 can be a string, to make the program show a different answer.<n>

He constantly worried about what? Choices:  A: the reward money B: hurt feelings C: being found out D: problems E: trouble<n><n>### Response:		<n>A.<n><n>### Input<n>A plane is flying at an altitude of 15,000 feet.  What distance will it travel in 4 hours?<n><n>### Response<n>  `4,7179`<n><n>### Instructions<n>If plane is traveling 450 miles per hour <n>If plane flies for 4 hours <n>Then distance traveled is `6,000 miles`<n><n>If a plane flies 400 miles per hour, how far will it travel in 1 hour? <n>Then the distance traveled is <n><n>### Code Snippet:<n>```<n>  if planeFlies=4<n>  then<n>    hoursA = (4/(5760)) # 4/7200 because hrs/60<n>    milesAFlted = (planeTravelSpeed)/(milesPerHour) #planeSpeed/mph<n>  end<n>  <n>  if planeFly=1<n>  then<n>    ifmilesFly = planTravelSpeed/milesPerHour<n>```<n>  Distance flied in 1 hour = (planeFlies x flightSpeed)/milesPerHour <n><n>### Input 2<n>A square has 64 centimeters on each side.  One of the corners has a radius of 20 centimeters.  The other three corners all have a radius of 30 centimeters. What is the radius of the circle?<n><n>### Answer<n>radius = 27.82 cm<n><n>### Response 1<n>```<n>square with sides = 64 cm<n>then<n>radius (for one of the corner) = 20<n>Then 30 = (R+20)/2<n>Then R = 20 * 5/2<n>Then R = (5*4)/2 = 12.5<n>Then RR = 12.3<n>```<n>### Solution 2<n>```<n>4s^2<n>=30^2<n><n>then 964=302<n>then square = 64<n>```<n>### Question<n>How many cents are in a dollar?<n><n>### Input A<n>If the price per pound is $0.40 and the weight of a box

He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. There is a ticket machine next to the entrance gate. How much coin can she put to get a discount and be able to purchase a ticket?  Tickets cost $1.25 and she has 5 1-dollar bills.<n><n>### Response<n>Input:Tina's maximum purchase is $5 because 5x1 = 5, 4 x 0.25 = 25/4 =$6.25.<n><n>### Hint:You can use a tape diagram for this problem. Or you can use addition, multiplication and division.<n><n>### [1,2,3,4]<n><br/><n><br/><n>### Input<n>There are 14 students in 5th grade. 90% of the students have a dog. If the probability of having a dog is 10%, how many students do not have a dog?<n><n>### Response <n>Input:The number of students that do not have a dog is 5. <n><n>### HINT:If each student has a dog, 14*1=14. So the total number of students is 15x10%=15/.90=16.5. Here,16.5 is the number of students that have a dog.

A palindrome is a string where when you read it backword every character is the same.<n><n>### Note:A programm that should take user inputs from the command line as well as read an input from a file.<n><n>### Create 3 methods in the program<n><n>Method 1, 2 are public.<n>- First ask the user for input on whether they have a file in mind to read.<n>- If they do, give them options to change/correct their input.<n>- If they don't, ask them for the input<n>  - The format of this method is a string<n>  <n>- Method 2 should ask the user for the file name, the format of this is a string.<n>  - Once they are in the loop of the method the file they entered will be opened and a 'for loop' will be used to read the contents of the file one character at a time.<n>  <n>- Once they are out, we should print the entire palindrome so the user knows it worked<n><n>Method 2 is not public<n>- This method will use the output from method 1 and will 'for loop' <n>  - If the file starts with something that isnt a string, and you cannot proceed to the next line, break out of the loop, return a message and exit from the program <n>  - If it doesnt, keep reading and print<n>  <n>- Once it runs through the 'for loop' it should 'for loop' and print<n>  <n>### Output<n><n>[Output here]<n><n>### Instructins:Create a method that takes in the length of a palindrome, as well as the contents of the palindrome. This method will check to see if the list of characters entered by the user is a palindrome or not.<n><n>### Notes:<n>- Method should take in a

His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Where is there usually a fiddle playing? If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Where can meat last a long time? Choices:  A: backery B: ham sandwich C: fridge D: butcher shop E: freezer<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>## Question<n> <n>In which place is meat most likely to stay fresh for a long time? 1. A: bakery 2. B: ham sandwich 3. C: fridge 4. D: butcher shop 5. E: freezer <n><n><n>## Explanation<n>I think the choices are butcher shop, freezer and fridge. They are both in a place.<n><n><n>### Check my work<n><n> 1. Choices: 1. B: ham sandwhich (fresh meat in a sandwhich will be hard to stay fresh) 2. C: fridge, (fridge can let meats be preserved, and the meat can last up to 100 years if it well stored) 3. D: Butcher shop (Meat will probably not last as long in butcher shop, because butchers often cut too much to cut the price) 4. E: freezer, (The butcher shop can preserve meat for a long time, it would stay for the longest time in a freezer.) 5. A: backery, (bakery is not relevant. backery would not be relevant, it's not even in any other answer.) <n>

His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What will happen to skin pinched in something? Choices:  A: feel cold B: feel pressure C: feel bumpy D: itches E: feel clammy<n><n>### Response:		Answer choices: (A) B (E)<n><n>### Inputs:Sally went to the market to buy some food for the next week and she spent on the food $48, the total cost of the milk  the week it will be cheaper is 2/3 of the cost of total milk. <n><n>### Response : Answer:<n><n><n>### Input :(B)<n><n>### Response :(D)<n><n>### The code should execute to print the following:25.<n><n>### Input:(C)<n><n>### Solution:(E):<n><n>### The name of the main character who narrates the story is:<n><n>### If I were to ask you about the character names, you should tell me:<n><n>### The main character's name is:<n><n>## Instructions:<n>Write a response that appropriately answers the question. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Where is a tabby cat likely to be happiest? Choices:  A: box B: home C: alley D: lap E: barn<n><n>### Response:		<n>The answer to where is a tabby cat most?likely to be happy, can be answered from looking at choices B,E, and A in order but in no way should the answer to this question be based one the word's in the title but should relate to the question.<n><n>The choice "home" most likely relates to the word "happy" in the title but does not relate to the question and can be excluded from the answer from elimination.  Likewise the words "lap" and "alley" don't have anything to do with the word "happiest" but instead focus on the words "tabby cat" in the title. Thus the choice A,E, B can be reduced to E and B.  Then we look at the options B and E to see which one is more likely.  E is definitely the answer and has to do with "home" related terms with the question.<n>

Some answers may contain more than one correct interpretation. Write an individual response for each of the 4 options provided below.<n><n>### **Option I**<n><n>### **Refer to the figure shown above**<n><n>### Answer:<n>The code specifies to select a row within column A and then copy the entire row. The code also specifies the selection start within Column B.<n><n>### Option II<n><n>### Refer to the figur shown above<n><n>### Answer;<n>The code specifies the first row within column A and the first row within column B. The second row within column B will not be copied and the last row within column A will be deleted from the range. The last row within column B will be the selection end and copied to another range.<n><n>### Choose the option that correctly completes the request. To help you solve this problem, we give you a code snippet.<n><n>### Code:<n>Sub Macro2()<n><n>For l = 1 To 11<n><n>Selection.Range("$A" & l) = Selection.Range("$B" & l) & Selection.Range("$C" & l)<n><n>Next<n><n>Next<n><n>End Sub<n><n>### Requirement:<n><n>### Write a macro, named MACRO2, that will search through the column A, B and C for values and only then copy the values to the new sheet starting from selection A3 and ending at I3.<n><n>Option I was answered correctly.<n><n>Option II was answered correctly.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Where do you put a new dining table? Choices:  A: cafeteria B: arranging papers C: in the park D: formal dining room E: house<n><n>### Response:		<n>D.<n><n>### InputÔºöJim always leaves work at 5:30 and starts eating dinner at 6:00. His dinner takes him 50 minutes to eat and he goes out of the house at 7:00 to go to the movies. If he leaves for the movies at 7:05, when will he get home from the movies?<n><n>### ResponseÔºö10:05<n><n>### Instructions:<n>If you get to choose all the time, what time will you set to wake up?<n><n>If you set the alarm to 5 am, 5:45 am and 6 am, the alarm will ring at 6:30 am.<n><n>Then please choose the time you want to wake up and the time you want alarm to ring. Remember, you may not choose a time that is not on the list.<n><n>### Requesting data<n><n>### Instctions:<n>Please calculate the sum of your expenses in December, 2016 and January, 2017.<n>Asked for: the sum of expenses in December and January<n><n>```<n>Expenditures in dollars,  Dec. 2016, $10.50<n>Expenditures from December 30 and 31, $0.90<n>Expenditues in dollars, Jan. 2017, $13.19<n>Expenditues from January 27 and 28, $3.52<n>```<n><n>### Responses<n>```<n>Please tell me the sum.<n><n>The sum of all expenses: 4,399<n><n>Please tell me the expenses on Dec. 30 and on Jan. 28<n><n>Dec. 30: $0.90 Jan. 28: $3.52 <n>```<n><n>## #<n>##

Choices:  A: stress B: food C: that you D: spending money E: walking<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct option is A.<n><n>If the person is likely to go in to market, they would likely stress, foods or spend money for something they wants.<n><n>Option A: Stress refers to mental, emotional or physical pressure or tension. This option is correct.<n><n>Option B: Food refers to one thing someone can eat. This option is incorrect<n><n>Option C: That you refers to yourself. Using such wording is not logical.<n><n>Option D: Spending money refers to the act of using currency and paying for goods. This option is incorrect.<n><n>Option E: Walking refers to standing, moving or travelling on foot. The question is not about walking.This option is incorrect.<n>

A weather person says it is at least 20 degrees and less than 100 degrees. Which weather forecast statement is incorrect?<n><n>### Response<n><n>A) ‚ÄúThe weather in the US should be hot.‚Äù <n><n>B) ‚ÄúThe weather in US will at least be 15 degrees, and less than 95 degrees‚Äù<n><n>C) ‚ÄúThe weather in all US should be hot‚Äù<n><n>D) ‚ÄúThe weather in Australia will be at least 40 degrees and below 66 degrees‚Äù<n><n>### Response <n><n>C) ‚Äú The weather in all US should at least be 100 degrees and at least 90 degrees‚Äù is an inaccurate forecast<n><n>### Input<n><n>The weather in the US will be at least 20¬∫F and less than 90¬∫F. The weather in US will NOT be at least be 80¬∫F and less that 115¬∫F<n><n>### Input <n><n>### Solution <n><n>```csharp<n>public static string Question(string q,string m)<n>{<n>    string ans ="";<n>    if(m=="A")<n>    {<n>        ans= q;<n>    }<n>    else<n>    {<n>        if(m=="B")<n>        {<n>            ans = "No, the temperature should be less than 105 degrees. It should not be less than 85 degrees.";<n>        }<n>        else if(m=="C")<n>        {<n><n>            ans = "It does not make sense to make such a forecast. ";<n>        }<n>        if (m=="D")<n>        {<n>             ans = "It should be at least 65¬∫F";<n>        }<n>        return ans;<n>    }<n>}<n><n>```<n>

How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:In the middle of the day what will someone do because of being hungry? Choices:  A: cook dinner B: make bread C: eat in restaurant D: have lunch E: make bread<n><n>### Response:		Input should be a string. You should have a variable x that contains one of the values of A, B, C, D, or E. Print "you will eat".<n>

Choices:  A: flower B: animal C: flower petals D: vegetable E: alive<n><n>### Response:		<n>Tom is ready for lunch! He goes to the fridge and asks for a sandwich. You have two different types to choose from. <n><n>* Ham: costs $4 and has the label "Treat 3"<n>* Peanut Butter: costs $3 and has the label "Nourish 2"<n><n>You open the fridge and discover that the label "Treats" on the shelf with the Ham is in fact "Nourish 1", and the label "Nourishes" on the shelf for Ham is in fact "Treat 2". <n><n>On the shelf for peanut butter, there are both labels present.<n><n>Which sandwich does Tom have in his hand, and what do you think is true for each of their prices?<n><n>Answers: Tom's sandwich is the one with "Treat 1" on it. Peanut butter should be more expensive than the Ham. **I want to make sure they are following the process of thinking about what they read (or hear) and then putting those thoughts into words.**<n><n>### Output:<n>You have a pet fish that was born last year when the fish store said it was a year old. For each month since you've owned it, write a sentence saying how old it is in years and months since you got the pet, and how old it is if it was born last year. For example, after one month and one day, you ask your friend, "How old is my fish?" He answers, "One year and one month," meaning that the fish is 13 months old and one month since you got it. After two months and one day, you say to your friend, "How have you been? My fish is 15 months and one month since I obtained it."<n><n>### Expected Output:<n><n>#### 1. Your pet's age (in years) was one month.<n><n>#### 2. Your pet's remaining age (in months) was one month. **You also write in a place for people to record that.***<n><n>#### 3. Your pet's overall age is two months.<n> <n>#### 4. Your pet's time since birth is one year and two months.<n>

How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. Choices:  A: mail orders B: demand satisfaction C: place money on counter D: pay merchants with money E: spend money<n><n>### Response:		<n>A,B and C are all types of shopping.<n><n>### Input :If a square‚Äôs diagonal is 12 cm and its side is 3 cm what is its area?<n><n>### Response :<n>We first need to know which is the bigger side in order to multiply with the bigger number and then the result. Side will be 12/3=4 and if the sides of a square are always four units(or a square is formed of 4 equal squares), then the diagonal will be 2*4=8 cm. So the bigger number for diagonal is 8 and for area calculation we get:<n>```<n>A=s*(s-4)=8*8=64<n>```<n>so the area of the square is 64.<n><n>###Input:<n>The distance between the cities St Petersburg and Moscow is about 850 km. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Many addicts turn to exercise to deal with their addictions, this is because it is a healthy way to do what? Choices:  A: condition heart B: expend energy C: laugh D: stretch E: weigh<n><n>### Response:		<n>A is right, B is wrong, C is right,<n>D is wrong, E is right<n><n>### Input :A man had 12 oranges in the morning, 4 apples in the afternoon and 10 bananas in the evening. How many fruits were he eating daily? Choices: A: 12 B: 32 C: 40 D: 100<n><n>### Response<n><n>A is right,<n>B is wrong,<n>C is wrong,<n>D is right<n><n>## Explanation :<n>This is because a man eating fruits, and the question asks for a response for the total number of fruits he is eating day by day.<n><n>### Input<n>An addict had an addiction of consuming 150 cups of alcohol every month, for how much they had drunk from the first month they had consumed the first time?<n><n>### Response :<n>They had 150 cupped alcohol for first month<n><n>### Input:-The price of every item in the supermaket increased. The owner of the supermarket sold every item with a 4% more expensive than before. <n>He sold the items and earned 43,000$. <n>What is value (in Dollars) of every item in the start?<n>### Response : <n>3760<n><n>### Input -A store sold a pair of jeans for 885 dollars and a shirt for 533 dollars. If all items in the store sold for $1000 what is the sale price of another store with 2 more store.<n>### Response : Other store sell all items for 710 and  a pair of jeans and shirt for each store for 283.<n><n>### Explanation :- <n>This is because with the increase in price of every item, the sale of jeans and shirts also increased.<n><n>### Question<n>How much is 1/4 of 1/4 of a gallon of milk?<n><n>### Answer : <n><n>4/25 gallon of milk, which is 8 ounces<n><n>### Question:<n><n>1/3 of 1/6 of 1/3 is 60th of what?<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. John bought they because he knew that they would look good.  Where might they be installed? Choices:  A: kitchen B: pantry C: containing pots and pans D: in a flight E: mexico<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>1. Identify the missing item(s).<n>2. Give one complete item(s) that will allow the correct answer choice to be displayed.<n><n>### Input 2:<n><n>1. John was taking care of some of the family's accounts.  He had $10.  The milk cost $2, the paper cost $0.25 and the stamps were $0.20.  Did he have enough money to buy all items? How much money did he need to make sure the milk wasn't the only item he bought that day?<n><n>### Response 2:<n><n>Input:<n><n>$2 from milk + $0.25 from paper + $0.20 from stamps = $2.45<n><n>If $10 was all the money he would have, he wouldn't have any money left and would need another $7.55 to make sure milk is the only thing not purchased.<n><n>### Output 2:<n><n>### Input<n><n>Input:<n>$4, $2, $50, 2, $5.00, 100<n><n>```<n>1. The amount in the register is $64.  Which choice describes how much more money does the cashier need to have in the register to complete her transaction? Choices: 1- $6<n>2. $36 from the register + $20 from the customer's payment = $56<n><n>3. If all her customers spent at least $5.00 each, the cashier would have at least $100 dollars in her register!<n>```<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Instruct:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Demo:<n>Input:  The amount in the register, $87.50 and a customer's payment of $15, which choice best describes the amount of money that the cashier needs to have in her register to complete the transaction?<n><n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: The cashier was given $64, with payment of $20 the money she needed to make change for a customer's payment would be?<n><n>Answer: $56<n><n>Input: All her customers spent at least how much to reach an amount of $100

Choices: A 50 grams B 150 grams C 200 grams D 250 grams E 300 grams<n><n>### Response <n><n>- <n><n># Question 5<n>### Instruction<n>Input: <n>- If a bat and a ball cost $1.10, how much will it cost for 10 bats and 10 balls?  <n>- If it takes 5 machines 5 minutes to make 5 widgets, then how many widgets will 10 machines make in 10 minutes? <n><n>### Demostration: <n>(Answering one question from instruction, choose from 2)<n><n>- 5 * 5 = 5 * 5 <n>- 5 * (5 *.5) = 5 * 10 <n> <n>### Input: <n>- The recipe calls for 1/2 a cup of sugar and 1/2 a teaspoon salt. How many cups are in 2/3 cup of sugar?<n>- If a bike and a helmet cost $11, how much money does the helmet cost?<n><n>### Response by writing code: <n><n>#### Python<n><n>    def 2_1(x,y):<n>        return x+y<n><n>    <n>    def 22(x,y): <n>       return x/y<n>       <n>#### Ruby<n>```<n>def 2_1(a,b)<n>  a+b<n>end<n>``` <n><n>#### Perl<n>```<n>sub 2_1($a,$b)<n>  $a+=$b<n>end<n>```<n><n>### Instructions

Choices: A: They died in a massive explosion, B: They were eaten by a man named Michael, C: They became extinct, D: They were eaten and then became extinct.  Answer:  C<n><n>### InputÔ∏∞ What is the formula used in finding elapsed time? Choices: A: time/speed B: distance/speed C: speed*time D: time*distance E: distance/speed*time Answer: Choice:D Elapsed time is the time that has passed since something started. Let's say you're timing an essay. You start your stopwatch at the exact second that the student begins speaking and you stop the stopwatch when the last word is spoken. The elapsed time is the number of seconds from when the student began speaking to the moment the stopwatch said "Time's Up." This is a common situation but you'll likely see the formula in science or math class. Let's look at an example.<n>### Instuction: Answer the multiple choice question.<n>### Demonstation:<n>### Input:   The first step in finding the area of the shape is to find what? A: The width or height. B: The volume. C: The diameter or radius. D: The value of x by changing the letter x in a formula. Answer: B<n><n>### Input  You want to buy a laptop and you know you want one with the best specs for your budget. This means you want a screen size of least 12 inches and should be able to get at least 8GB of memory. How much is at least 8GB worth? Do this using addition/subtraction and multiplication/division. A: 459 B: 640 C: 738 D: 800 E: 940 Answer: D<n>$640=8GB<n>

This question is asking for where it would be but the answer is that it would be in a flower garden so it would be in an area that is filled with flowers not vegetables or other things.<n><n>### Input:"Rosemary" is the name of a flower.  Which of these choices best matches the word FLOWER to "rosemary"? Choices:  A. The color of a flower B. The part of a plant that produces flowers C. An area in the world where you find flowers growing D. The name of a plant that produces many small flowers E. The part of the plant where seeds are produced<n><n>### Response:"An area in the world where flowers grow."<n><n>### Justifications:<n>The definition of flower that was given is "The part of a plant where seeds are made." The word FLOWER was replaced with ROSEMARY and then replaced with FLOWER. It can only mean that it's an area where flowers grow or another part of a plant like a seed that produces a flower because that's what the word plant is defined as.<n><n>### Your turn:Input:What kind of animals are called _ducks_? Choices:  P: A: birds B: lizards C: worms D: bats E: rabbits

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. So, what is the resulting number?<n><n>### Respose<n><n>The resulting number is 43.<n><n>### <n>The resulting number is zero.<n>

Then what part of an assignment does Shanti complete each minute?<n><n><n>### Answer <n><n>If Sara takes three times longer to complete an assignment than Shanti then Shanti is twice as fast as Sara. Shaanti is twice as fast. To complete one part of an assignment in minute, Sara takes three times to finish one part of an assignment as Shanti (and vice versa). Therefore, to complete an assignment in three times the number of minute, Sara takes triple the minute that it takes Shanti to complete the same assignment.<n><n>### Input<n><n>Input: It takes 3 minutes for the car to travel 86 miles. His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65. How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:How can buildings like the Empire State building be described? Choices:  A: small B: underground C: high D: huge E: tall<n><n>### Response:		You can compare how high a building is compared to the building with the largest or highest.<n>### Detailed Solution<n>The answer is option B: Underground.<n>

How many of the students are female?<n><n>### Response :<n>6/3 of the males have been chosen that means there are 84 females and <n><n>2 x 64/3 is 48.<n>48 x3/2 is 144.<n>144 x3/2 is192.<n>So 128 -192 is 36 which means there are 36 females in the class<n><n><n>### Input A:128<n>### Response<n>48 x 1/2 x 64 is 64 or 6 females.<n><n>100-64 is 36 therefore the answer is 36+6 is 42<n><n><n>### <n>756739978<n><n>756723937<n><n>100101010<n><n>1236456543<n><n>34233229438<n><n>1329364658<n><n>9853235859<n><n>12868998776<n><n>11956068644<n><n>2387923886<n><n>11856666763<n><n>99000020958<n><n>87538185368<n><n>13677495288<n><n>10935758459<n><n>27835965477<n><n>8526767378<n><n>

Choices:  A: heart transplant B: distance himself C: perform surgery D: study medicine E: let blood<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### A:  heart transplant<n><n>#### B: distance himself<n><n>#### C: perform surgery<n><n>#### D: study medicine<n><n>#### E: let blood<n>  <n>### Input: What did the doctor say to his patient after checking her reflexes as part of her regular check-up?  Choices: A: I will send the bill.  B: I need to get another doctor.  C: You don‚Äôt have good reflexes.  D: It looks as though your reflexes are about 3 feet long.  E: I like your shoes.<n><n>### Response<n><n><n>#### A: I will send you the bill<n><n>#### B: I need to find another doctor<n><n>#### C: You don't have good reflexions<n><n>#### D: It looks as if your reflexes are long 3 feet<n><n>#### E: I like your shooess<n><n><n>Input: <n>What is the difference between "mammal" and "molecule?"<n><n><n>#### C1: A: mammal is an animal that a human uses to make milk, and the scientific term for molecule is "mole."<n><n>#### C2: C: "Molecule" is a scientific term for the smallest parts that make up a substance. A mammal is an adult human or animal that produces milk.<n>  <n>#### C3: E: A: "Mammal" is the scientific name of the smallest part that makes up a substance.  B: molecule is a scientific term for animal that produces milk.   C: molecule is the scientific term for animal that anatomically resembles man, which is not true.  D: molecule is an organic compound that a human takes.<n>  <n>----------------------------------<n><n>#### A: mammal comes from the Latin word "mamma" meaning breast<n><n>#### B: molecule comes from the Greek meaning small part of an atom<n><n>#### C: mammal refers to all animals who produce milk<n><n>#### D: molecule refers to all living things<n><n><n>#### A1:  molecule means small part of an atom and is from Greek<n><n>#### A2:  molecule comes from Greek and means small part of an atomic<n><n><n>#### B:
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:They were competing in basketball, the goal was to what? Choices:  A: bounce the ball B: competition C: have fun D: race E: score points<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is D: race.<n><n>### Input : They were competing in basketball. Choices:  A : competition B : fun C : bounce d: have <n><n>### Response : The correct answer is C: FUN<n><n>### Input - How many pizza should we make? Choices: A. Two B. 15 C. Six D. 30<n><n>### Response - the correct answer is D:30<n>

His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. They have prepared the following list of questions for aspiring writers to answer to help them determine who is best suited for the job. 1.  Have you ever written a story in your life? 2.  Have you read any of the other books published by this publisher in the past? 3.  Have you taken courses that relate to writing? 4.  Do you have a job? 5. Are you married? 6. What are your hobbies? 7.  Who are your role models? 8.  What is your motivation for becoming a writer? The publisher is considering applicants who answered yes to every question. What percentage of applicants are being considered for the job? Round your answer to.<n><n>### Response5:50%.<n><n>### Inputs 6&7:Use the answers from the previous two tasks to create the sentence below.<n><n>### Answer, not Input:6/7, 600,201<n><n><n>### Input8:What is the lowest common multiple of 8 and 12?<n><n>### Answer:24<n><n>### Input9:Ron had 4 coins. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. There was a target on the wall for him to bounce against.  Where might he be? Choices:  A: pool table B: toy box C: playroom D: park E: closet<n><n>### Response:		<n><n><n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write an efficient method that takes in a pair of Strings and returns true if they have the same length. If they don't have same length, make sure to return false.<n><n>### Input<n><n>Input is taken in the form on a method called  Check String Lengths where method parameters  String First String and String Second String are passed. It then  returns a boolean variable of type boolean indicating a true value if  the string length of First String equals that of Second String.  Otherwise, it needs to return a false value.<n><n>### Output<n><n>The Output of the method should be in the form of a new boolean variable of type boolean stating whether  or not the string length of First and Second String of type String,  passes the check based on their lengths.<n><n>### Expected Value<n>If the length of First String is equal to the length of Second String, a value of true will return from the method. Otherwise, the method will return a false value.

He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. The prompt asks two questions to get to one, which is how many dollars did each parent give?<n><n>### Step 1<n>Write down two steps that lead to the answer.<n><n>1.  Write 3*4 on a paper.<n>2.  Subtract the smaller number from the larger number.<n><n>### Step2<n>Step 2 is: 3*4 = 12 12-4 = 8<n><n><n>### Step3<n>Step 3 is: 8 - 4 = 4<n><n>### Step4<n>Step 4 is: 4 - 4 = 0<n><n><n>### Summary and self-evaluation<n>How could you improve your overall response?<n><n>### Challenge<n>Given that you've solved the challenge, could you take on the challenge of making this response better?<n><n>

If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What European country is famous for its potato industry? His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:The animals weren't good at swimming, so it was hard for them to do what? Choices:  A: pass water B: bathe C: listen to each other D: feel pleasure E: reproduce asexually<n><n>### Response:		The animals weren‚Äôt good at swimming so it was hard for the them to listen to each other.<n><n>

In what proportion did it reduce?<n>Answer: 0.5<n><n>### Response<n><n>> If the number of apples increased by and then reduced by half, it reduced by 0.5.<n>><n>> 0.5 divided by the first number 2 = 0.5<n>><n>> 2 times 2 is 4 times as many as one time 2.  <n>> 4 times as many is 8 times as many<n><n><n>### Input : <n><n>Input: A chess board requires the space of 16 square of land,and an empty chessboard is 16 square of empty. <n>Then, how many empty spaces are on the chessboard?<n>Answer: 8<n><n>### Response : <n><n>> An empty chessboard is a board with 16 square of space (16 empty spaces)<n>><n>> Then an empty chessboard has 16 x 16 = 256 empty spaces<n>><n>> Since an empty chessboard doesn't occupy 16 square of spaces(a chessboard does)

I will recommend recursive solution for this problem as it is the easiest one: you can split the input word by'' character and recursively check all combinations, finally check if one of the letters is a vowel.<n>I have written an algorithm that solves this problem. Please take a look at the first function:<n>```<n>public static String findVowelsRecur(String str)<n>{<n>    if (str == null || str.isEmpty())<n>        return "";<n><n>    return findVowelsRec(str, str.length() - 1);<n>}<n>```<n>I will skip the code for another functions, you will find it in the link.<n><n><n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Johnny was looking for blowfish in places that weren't near America. "))<n>a = [2,3,5]<n><n># code 1.1<n>for i in range(4, 6):<n>    print(i*n)<n><n># code 2.1<n>for i,j in map(int,input().split()):<n>    print(j*i)<n><n><n>print("the difference")<n>for i,j,k in zip(a, range(4,6), range(6)):<n>    print(k*j)<n><n>```<n><n>```python<n># for-in loop on matrix<n>matrix = [[2,3],[9,8]]<n>for i, a in matrix:<n>    print(i

Each task in this section is a list of steps. You can complete each part after clicking a step.<n>## Step 1: Find<n><n>## Step1Finding Input: What number does 56 minus 72 equal?<n><n>## #Step1Finding Response:40

How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. Choices:  A: bathe B: bite C: die of cancer D: obesity E: copulate<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>A)<n><n>### Instructions: <n>Write a program that contains two methods, both with one parameter.<n>  <n>The first method is called CountStars and should use the StarCounter variable. Pass a string to the method that you wish to count stars in. That string should have the punctuation "!" removed. The program should return the size of the string after the number of stars were replaced with "".<n><n>The second method should be called CountSquares and should use the SquareCounter variable. Pass a number of spaces to the method, and that number of spaces should be placed anywhere in the string. The program should return a string containing the number of spaces.<n><n>### Example:<n><n>input: "Hello! world!" with 5 stars and 5 spaces<n>output: "Helloworld" <n><n><n>### Input<n>John is studying animals. What is one of the things he has to watch?  <n><n>### Response<n>A<n><n>### Instuctions<n>While developing your program, you should use the following files to save your work throughout the task.<n><n>- **File 1: TaskA.java** (This file with its related files is the working directory.)<n><n>---<n>### Instruction<n>Your program should be in the file: TaskA.java.<n>Create it using this template.<n><n>    public class TaskA {<n><n>    public static int starCounters, squareCounters; <n><n>        public static int CountStars(String s) {<n>            // <n>            // Add the code that you need here<n>            // <n><n>            return starCounters;<n>        }<n><n>        public static String CountSquares(int s) {<n>            s += " ";<n>            // Add the required code here<n>            //<n><n>            return squareCounters;<n><n>        }<n><n>    }<n><n>    // Testing methods<n><n>    public static final void test1() throws Exception {<n>        TaskA ta = new TaskA();<n>        ta.starCounters = 10;<n>        ta.squareCounters = 20;<n>        String str = "Hello! world!";<n>        ta.CountStars(str).toString();<n>        System.out.println();<n>        ta.CountSquares(3).toString();<n>        ta.
