Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What do rich people like in terms of bagels? Choices:  A: poor B: sleepy C: plain D: needy E: homeless<n><n>### Response:		Rich people do not really like plain bagels.  They like needy ones.  Rich people like to feel needed.  They want poor people and needy people to go out with them.  They like to see other people's poor and needy faces.  Rich people are very happy with needy bagels that aren't great bagels.<n><n>### Input:"B" is a very good bagel place."<n><n>### Response:"I think they do really well."<n><n>### Input:(Phrase meaning that the person does not like something.) Choices:  A.  Meh B.  eh C.  Nah D.  Ugh E.  Dang<n><n>### Response:(Phrase meaning the person likes it.) Choices: A.  Yum B.  Cool C.  I Love It D.  This is tasty E.  Yes<n><n>### Instructions:Write a response that describes a task.<n><n>### Output:"I'm looking for a pink and purple striped bathing top for my grandmother. She's short. The top must fit very loosely and she doesn't like it clingy. Please let me know when you find such a bathing top."<n><n>### Output: "Okay, I'll see what I can do for you."

He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:People want to explore space, so what should they use to do it? Choices:  A: public place B: roadblock C: space shuttle D: hoverboard E: supermarket<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: Choices: A D<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Answer the following multiple choice, and write a response that appropriately applies the skill.<n><n>### Input<n>**People want to explore the universe around us.**<n>**A:** There are multiple options for getting around the universe. It is possible through **public places, roadblocks, and space shuttles**.<n><n>**B:** There are multiple ways to explore space. **You can use roads, space shuttles, hoverboards, and supermarkets**. <n><n>### Response<n>**A:** The best way to explore space is to use **public places.** A **space shuttle** is the fastest way to travel at this time, and it also requires a great deal of fuel. It may require **roadblocks**, which slows down travel. Hoverboards only travel on very flat surfaces. In some places, you can only explore on the surface of the moon and not the solar system.<n>**B:** You can use roads to travel between nearby galaxies, but you have to be careful of space rocks. Space shuttles are faster, but require a lot of fuel. If you choose a space shuttle, you may need to drive around some roadblocks. Hoverboards are able to travel at high speeds because they can lift off the ground for a short distance. Supermarkets are only available in our galaxy.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:When he touched the exposed wire he shouldn't have found it surprising that he got what? Choices:  A: see work B: shocked C: humor D: startled E: funny<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### **Correct:**<n><n>### Instructions:The following sentences have capitalization problems. Write one of the appropriate forms in the box. You may not use the sentence exactly as written, but if you change your answer you must also show how the sentence is now corrected. Example: I see you there. becomes I see you there.<n><n>### Incorrect attempt:<n>They had a dog  the  _dog_  named  _Sparky._  _Sparky_  was a really goofy dog. I know he will have no issues getting that job.<n><n>### Correct:<n><n>### Instractions:<n>Find each of the following words in the box or letter section. Each letter may be used only once. To find a letter, it must contain the correct answer to the previous sentence. When you have found the correct letters, write the name of the animal.<n><n>### Word Bank:<n>1. A crab ape a dog a goat<n>2. A pig a rabbit a parrot a skylark<n>3. A bear a bird a cat a coon<n>4. A deer an elephant an emu an iguana<n>5. A moose a monkey a donkey a turkey<n>6. A frog a horse a zebra a kangaroo<n><n>### Response to above:<n><n>### Incorrect attempt:<n>Answer:<n>### Correct to above:<n><n><n>### Instructication:<n><n>In the example, the code snippet has 48 lines. One way to review the code and ensure that it is correct is to start at the beginning and use a procedure similar to this which counts the number of statements in the code to verify the number of statements is equal to the answer provided above. <n><n>```<n>FOR line = 1 TO lineNo END<n>	IF line = 48 GOTO done<n>	INSTRUCTION(line, lineNo)<n>	NEXT line<n>done:	IF lineNo = 48 GOSUB done<n>```<n><n>Here line and lineNo are variables which count upwards by the number specified by lineNo. They are declared in a FOR statement; line decrements lineNo by one if the test statement is true and lineNo increments lineNo by 1 if the test statement is false.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:The cow would come outside even after the storm had passed, it wouldn't leave the what? Choices:  A: meat grinder B: stable C: red barn D: gate E: green field<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions:This problem contains a question with multiple choice answers. Is the student correct?<n><n>### Output<n>No<n><n><n>### Output Expaination:<n><n>The input data shows that the number of squares with 44 indicates that there are at least 2099 squares in the paper.<n><n>### Implecations:<n><n>```<n>2099-44=2055<n>```<n><n>## Solution<n><n>### Instuction:<n><n>```<n>Write any other questions and comments.<n>```<n>

If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:A water spout was seen in the ocean off the coast of what? If the first player to place a marker on that board gets three in a row, then where would that player place the next marker?<n><n>### Response; On the player's first turn: C<n>The player places the third marker into the fourth box.<n>The player then checks to see if the player has three in a row (2 in each row).<n><n>If it is a win, the player places their last and third marker in the box.<n>Otherwise, the player resets the board.<n><n>### Input1:A 9 gallon container of juice and water is to be prepared. 1/3 of the container will be juice, 1/4 can is water and 1/6 of the remainder is milk. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What do you need to have before buying products? Choices:  A: desire B: spending money C: money D: needs E: time<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n>A<n>A<n>B<n>A

E) A horse.<n><n>### Response D<n><n>### Instructions: For each question, decide if the given statement is true or false.<n><n>If it‚Äôs true, mark T, if it‚Äôs false, mark F. Answer.<n><n>If the statement is false, the first part of the question tells you which part of the statement is wrong. If the statement is true, there will be no first parts of of the question.<n><n>## Q1:<n><n>A.	True<n>B.	False<n><n>Input: I'm a student at the university.<n>A.	The given statement is true.<n>B. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If there are 25 gallons left in their gas tank when they left home and they are traveling 10 miles per gallon, how long will the trip take them? Round your answer to the nearest tenth of a mile.<n><n>### Response :<n>6 hours and 25 minutes or 415 minutes.<n><n>### Input<n>The car had an average mileage of 27 mpg and travelled 8 gallons more. If they need 10 gallons for their trip, then they have used 10 gallons - 8 gallons they used in their drive before the trip and their actual fuel required to cover the trip is 8 gallons + 10 gallons = 18 gallons.<n>Then multiply 18 gallons by 10 miles per 1 gallon and their total required fuel for the trip is<n><n>18*10 = 180 miles<n><n>and their required fuel is 10 (difference between calculated and actual fuel)<n><n>### Input <n>We have fuel requirement 10 gallons<n><n>We have actual fuel 18 gallons<n><n>Thus remaining fuel -18 gallons - 10 gallons= 8 gallons (remaining fuel not enough to cover their total fuel requirement)<n><n><n><n>### Input How many days can John make from $15.00?<n><n>### Response <n>John can make 15 days.<n><n>### Explain : John can make 360*15= 5400 which is rounded to 5400 hence John can make 5 400 √∑ 5 = 11 day. 1 day is there is a remainder.<n><n>### Write the following expression with parentheses.<n><n>(((5 * 5)+4)+3)<n><n>### Write a function that calculates the area.<n>Area is calculated as below using a formula.<n><n>L1*W1 + L2*W2 +... + Ln*Wn<n><n>### Demosnsrate the calculation.<n><n>The following are the inputs :<n>Inputs L1, L2, W1, W2, L3, L

Answer: A: 10<n><n>### Input F: All cars manufactured after the year 2000 will have which feature? Answer: B: Airbags<n><n>### Input G: A car that has had its airbags deployed should not be resold, traded in, or sold to a repair shop for what time frame? Answer: D: The car should not be sold anywhere near a car rental company<n><n>### Input H: It's common for tires to develop a leak when their pressure is lower than a certain PSI. At what PSI should drivers not adjust the pressure of the tires when filling their tires? Answer: C: 5<n><n>### Input I: The octane rating of gasoline is always stated in which units? Answer: B: Rating system<n><n>### Input J: The "check engine" light will show on vehicles when the fuel system becomes malfunctioned. When will the warning be visible in most car models? How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. Choices:  A: surrender B: defence C: retreat D: cease fire E: defend<n><n>### Response:		 <n><n>### Input and Answer choices:<n>Input: A tree is 16 feet in length. What is 30 percent of this tree's length?<n>Answer:   5 feet<n><n>Input: A tiger is 5 inches longer than a rabbit. If the rabbit weighs 20 pounds, how much longer is the tiger?<n>Answer:  10 inches<n><n>Input: David‚Äôs new house has a square footage of 42 x 48, and the rent is $3276. How much is the rent per square foot?<n>Answer:    $75.56<n><n>Input: You need to buy some gifts for the holiday season. What was the average amount of apples per basket?<n>Answer: 878.494 apples per basket<n><n>Input: What is 610 less than the product of 264 and 90?<n>Answer:   9363<n><n>### Instructions:<n>1. Input a question into the prompt with any number of variables (e.g. x, y, z).<n><n>2. The machine will generate 2 random numbers and the sum of these two numbers. These will be your starting points for a two variable system.<n><n>3. Generate your questions with two variables (e.g x and y), where your answer will be a value.<n><n>4. Choose the correct answer or if more correct answers are given, use the input prompts to generate new questions.

His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:The shore was now a tourist attraction with nearby little shops, but at one time this what was home to a bustling fishing industry? Choices:  A: seaside town B: resort C: ocean D: california E: beach<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input:(A) What is the smallest prime number?<n><n>### Response:(B) It's 47.<n><n>### Input :(A) Jack has 5 pairs of gloves. One-half are blue and half are black. If there are 3 pairs blue and 2 pairs black, how many pairs are blue?<n><n>### (B) There are 7 pairs blue.<n><n>### Output:<n>(A) If x is a number less than 7 and less than __, then __.<n><n>Write an expression:<n><n>(B) If x is a positive integer, the number of letters in the word x- 1 is ___ more than the number of letters in x.<n><n><n>### Solve by Partial Pairs<n><n>I have a bag of 30 marbles.  If I separate out all the red marbles, and all the blue marbles, I end up with 10 red marbles and 10 blue marbles. I have 20 more marbles in the bag. How many of these remaining marbles are red?<n><n>If I put together the remaining marbles and separate away all the red marbles and all the white marbles, I end with 50 marbles and 20 are red. How many marbles are white?<n><n>Write expressions:<n><n>(A) If the total number of marbles in the bag is represented by the un-nested fraction, then the number of red marbles in the bag, after 20 have been put together, is represented by the nested fraction. In other words, 1‚ÅÑ2 equals 1 red marble plus 1‚ÅÑ5.<n><n>(B) The expression for how many white marbles are left in the bag after 20 has been put together is equal to the difference of 1‚ÅÑ2 and 1‚ÅÑ5.

It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Someone who doesn't care about about someone else and wishes them to fail has what feeling towards them? Choices:  A: unfeeling B: negligence C: antipathy D: indifferent E: rapport<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### HW:<n>(https://www.codecademy.com/learn/lessons/what-are-pseudocodes?step=4)<n><n>- (T)<n>- (R)<n>- (F)<n>- (A)<n>- (L)<n>- (S)<n>- (W)<n><n>### Input<n><n>A group is planning a trip to the countryside.  Five members will drive over together and then rent a house.  The rest will drive separately or take a bus. <n><n>They want to rent a house with at least the capacity of a 5-person van (the largest vehicle that any of the group could drive).  100% is when there are enough beds for each bedroom + a folding bed in the living room.  The group must agree on a single house.  If none of the houses they consider satisfies the capacity criteria, they will settle on the best available.<n><n>This solution assumes that 100% always equals 5 person's capacity.  Since there are 5-person transportation options, 200% should also equal 5 persons, 250% should also equal three (possibly with two folding beds in the living room) and so on. <n><n>The following code can determine which houses should be considered for rental:<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>- (T)/(R)/(F)/(A)/(L)/(S)/(W)<n><n>Input:<n><n>```<n>7<n>7<n>8<n>3<n>4<n>9<n>9<n>3<n>11<n>7<n>6<n>3<n>7<n>6<n>6<n>7<n>6<n>7<n>8<n>7<n>7<n>6<n>12<n>5<n>6<n>6<n>2<n>5<n>7<n>7<n>7<n>5<n>12<n>11<n>10<n>6<n>8<n>9<n>9<n>9<n>8<n>-2<n>-4<n>6<n>```<n><n>Output:<n><n>```<n>5<n>	-Because there's no 5-room house and 30% is not enough.<n>	If no more 5-bed-room house<n>	6<n>-Because they have to have a 5-room house<n>	7<n>	-The last option has 5 beds plus a folding bed
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:My favorite type of entertainment are rollercoasters and ferris wheels, where should I go? Choices:  A: theatre B: fairgrounds C: friend's house D: show E: casino<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct answer to this question is C: friend's House D: Show F: Casino<n><n>### Justification:<n>The answer with the correct answer letter is D. The answer with the correct answer number is F. The answer with the choice letter ‚ÄúC‚Äù is the correct answer.<n><n>### Input : What is the area of the following triangle? 6,6,10<n><n>### Response :<n>The correct answer to the question would be B.<n><n>### Justifications :<n>The answer with the choice letter "B" is the correct answer. The answer with the answer number "106" is wrong. The answer with the letter "A" is wrong. The choice "C" is the least correct answer and the the answer the "154" is wrong.<n><n>### Challenge Input :<n>The dog weighs 1/6 of the cat<n><n>### Challenge response:<n>The answer with letter "C" is the correct answer to the challenge<n><n>### Challenge justification :<n>The answer with number "C" has a letter "C" that is the correct answer. the answer letter with "B" is not an answer<n>

Choices:  A: skate B: play piano C: fiddle D: play piano E: have fun<n><n>### Response:		Choice: Play piano<n><n>### Explanation:<n>If the subject is an action then the predicate is an action. So the verb 'play' is an action. If the subject is a noun and the predicate ends in -ing it is a present participle and can be the predicate.<n>![ScreenShot](Ex8.png)<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Description:<n>In the exercise given below, there is a story. John made a snowman last week.<n>2. A bird broke the snowman's nose.<n>3. Linda fixed the snowman's face.<n>4. John lost track of where his hat and scarf went.<n>5. Linda helped John look for the snowman's accessories.<n>6. The snowman went missing.<n>7. They searched for the snowman.<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Choice: Linda helped John look.<n><n>### Explination:<n><n>### Choices:<n><n>### Input 4<n><n>### Story:<n>1. Sam had two cans of soda.<n>2. He left one can of soda in the car.<n>3. He drank half of one can of soda, making it 1/4 full.<n>4. He walked out to the garage.<n>5. He emptied the remaining soda.<n>6. He picked one of the cans of soda to throw.<n>7. Sam was too drunk to throw the soda can so he hit Randy instead.<n><n>### Choose: He hit Randy.<n><n>### Justified Answer:  Sam was drunk and he didnt want to throw it on the ground so he threw it at Randy instead and he hit him.<n>

It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Where are all participants likely to need sports equipment? (A: True or False B: False)<n><n>### Instructions:  If the dog's head is above the table, then it can eat a dog bone. <n><n>### Insturctions: if the dog's head can not be above the table then it can eat a bone<n><n>### Instuctions:if the dog's head had been above the table he could have eaten a bone <n><n>### Response<n>A. If the dog's was above the table he could had eaten a bone because he would not need the food.<n><n>### Response <n>A. The dog's head could be above the table but because there is food she is not interested in eating the bone.<n><n>### Question<n>1. How many books did she buy?<n>2. How many times more money did he need than the amount of the total number of books purchased times the number of his brothers?<n><n>### Response1:<n>1. 37 books<n>2. 3 times<n><n>### Response2:<n>1. No idea how many brothers there are or how much are the books, so I will assume each book is 19 dollars.<n>2. 37 + 19 x 3 = 23 x 3 = 69 + 19 = 88<n><n>### Question : <n><n>### Inroduction:<n>This is a puzzle, there is a puzzle which has been put in place, if we take off these numbers and add this number we would have the solution.<n><n>### Solution<n><n>863 - 345 + 46 = 2584<n><n>### Solution 1<n><n>1752 - 345 = 1407<n><n>### Solution2<n><n>643 - 341 = 182<n><n>### Question:<n>What number multiplied by 6 divided by 5 is 60?<n><n>### Solution:<n>7/2 x 6 = 15/6

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:The college kids weren't known for their apartment decor choices, they used a folding chair inside their what? Choices:  A: bathroom B: closet C: school D: room E: church<n><n>### Response:		closet<n><n>### Feedback:<n>This problem asks you to input two pieces of data and output the sum of those pieces of data. Answers are expected to contain integers.<n><n>Input: A college student has $2.63 for food this week.  Then he's going to be paid $5.97 for a job he does.  He wants to save a dollar to buy a new charger for his phone.  How much money does he have left for food?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: $186 + x = 50 (1)<n>$5 + $0.54 x < $7 (2)<n><n>$191.54 - x < $10 (3)<n><n>Solve the system (1), (2) and (3) to find out x.<n><n>Input: x = $7.47<n><n>Input: 92.6 is $137.69 plus $8 minus $8<n><n>### Output:<n>Answer:89.63<n><n>Input: (10)(20) = 200, (8) (10) = 80 (2) (3) (4)(6)<n><n>Answer: 225<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Input the expressions, and write the answer.<n><n>### Input 1: x (2) (3 (4)(5) 7 2<n><n>### Output 1:<n>Answer:14<n><n>### Input2: 5+ x <n><n>### Output2:<n>Answer:5<n><n>### Input3:  10+(9+3) (10-5) (4+2)3<n><n>### Output3:<n>Answer:30<n>

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What could you put a table in if you want the table to be in your house? Choices: A: restaurants B : casserole C : root cellar D : pockets E : pantry Purchasing stew at a restaurant is too expensive to be practical. Therefore, he should have located this potato in the root cellar.<n>### Input:Sam was given an allowance of $7.50. He spent $20.  After he spent that money, his grandfather and aunt each gave him $10.  If he still has $4.36 left over, how much money did he spend in the first place?<n><n>### Response<n>Input:Sam was given an $7.50 allowance and was able spend $20.  He then received an extra $10 from both his grandfather and aunty.  This money will allow him to spend $30 extra.  If he starts out with $7.50 and spends $20, he will have spent $38 total.  The final allowance he has left is $4.36.<n>### Input<n>Pete was playing a game, he went to a store and picked out a game out of 4. Each game cost $12. The game he chose cost double as much as his third cheapest choice, how much did he spent on total.<n><n>### Response - Answer:<n>Pete chose a game that cost $12 and he spent $24 on the total.<n>The only way he can afford to have $24 in total is if either 1) he picked the game that cost $10 or if 2) 4 times the game that cost him $24.<n>Pete chose the game that costs him $10.<n>### Input Sam had a collection of 55 cash.  Sam had a goal of adding up to $200 to his collection.  Sam wanted to buy an item for $17. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What were southern institutions where slaves do the labor called? Choices:  A: farm B: ancient rome C: history book D: poor countries E: plantation<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions: Input:If there are 16, 614 apples in a grove, and 5/6 of the apples are red, how many of the apples are green? Choices: A: 548 B: 984 ****** C: 1,399 D: 19,924 E: 36,072 ****** F: 32,088<n><n>### Response (A): How many green apples are there in the grove, in total?<n>### Demonstartion: 5/6 x 16,614<n><n>### Input/Demonstration/Response: (A) x (Green Apples)<n><n>### Instuctions: Choose (A), (B), (C), (D), (E), or (F).<n><n>* I think that the answer to this question is (A) because the ratio of red apples to green apples is 5/6. This means that green is 5/6, or 40% of the total apples. Because this is a decimal and not a percentage, you will have to use multiplication on 16,600 to find the answer to the question (If 5/6 of 1,660 = 40%, then what is the entire number?).<n><n>### Input and Instructions: <n><n>**Please be sure to include a screen shot of your work.**<n><n><n>[![Instruction:Answer the following statement. In 2000 the average salary was 3504. What is the average salary today, based on a minimum of 5 years of teaching experience?<n><n>Response: To solve, we need to first multiply the original value for years by its year's average income, then subtracting the total value of the average income from the minimum value of 5 year average income. So, for the question to be solved we need to find 685, 3504 and the answer which is at least 3615. We can find 685 in 1950 by multiplying 1.<n>Then we can find 3504 in 2000 by doing the same: multiply 1, the original value of years by its year' s average income. By doing so we get an answer of 6185 then, we add minimum average income 3615 to the answer we found earlier in 6185.<n><n><n>### Input 3<n><n>Input, Input: 5 people take a bus trip. The bus trip will cost $26 for the first person and $8 each for any additional passengers. How much will the group need to pay for the trip?<n><n>Response: <n>To solve the problem, you must calculate how much each person needs to pay for each person individually. We do this by finding the $26 for the 5th person and subtracting it from all other values. We can do this by saying, 26 is the $ of the fifth person - 74 is the 4th person (because it is 26(5) -74(4))<n><n>Next, we make sure all of our answers are in dollars so we can multiply it. So we are left with the 3rd person who would equal 74(2) - 74(2).<n><n>We can then solve with division since $74 divided by $8 equals 9.9 with a remainder of 4. To further simplify this fraction, we can re-write it as 4, because we know that 9

Choices: A: arlington - arlington is for national burial, not as cemetery of choice. B: cemetery - the graveyard can't be out back  it takes effort to maintain a graveyard.  C: church property  - church property is for church events not a graveyard. Churches own a lot of property. D: every town - The graveyard should have a location  that is most convenient  to the community that the graveyard is built  in. He had $1.63 in nickels, 95 pennies, and the rest quarters.  If George had $1.24 total in quarters, how much quarters does he have left?<n>### Response<n><n><n><n>**Solution:** This problem was answered correctly, because $1.24 is not the same as $1.26. (Remember, 4 quarters = $1 and 8 pennies = $0.10.)<n><n>### Input<n><n>B. There are 22 pencils in a box.  If each pencil has an odd number of legs, how many legs are there in a total of 52 pencils?  (Note: the answer is not 162)<n>### Response:<n><n><n><n>**Note:** There is a slight difference between this and the solution to problem B. The solution to B would indicate that each pencil had at least one odd number of legs. This would include cases where some pencils have 2, 3, or more legs. (In total, the sum of legs is supposed to be 52, not all the legs.)<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Demonstration:<n>Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n>### Instrucion:In order to win a trophy in a soccer tournament,<n>### Instruzione:In order to win  a trophy  in a soccer tournement  <n>### Instructione:In order to win   a trophy  in  a soccer tournement<n>### Instructiones:In order to win      a  trophy  in a   soccer tournement<n>

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What could fighting inflation cause if it is not successful? If 20 students are absent, then how many books do remaining students have?<n><n>### Response<n>```<n>There are 11 students in her class, then each book is assigned to five people. Among students, there are 10, then we subtract 1 to 9 people. Accordingly, there are 9 books in each student‚Äôs bag. Then subtract 20 people, and there are 5 books left in the students' bag.<n>```<n>### Instruction and Demonstration: Solve the problem.<n>```<n>Input: How many cats are there in the box including the black cat?<n>```<n>### Demonstraion:<n>```<n>There are only three in the box including the cat.<n>```<n>## Output: 4<n>### Instruction : Solve the problem. If Sam was sitting 8 rows from the left side of the stage, how many rows was Jerry from Sam?<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>Jerry was sitting in row "Q" and Sam was sitting in row "S". Q-O-M-E-W, O-E-F-T-W, E-F-T-U-L, F-H-U-S-K, H-S-S-L-A<n><n>### Response<n>If Jerry was sitting in an even number of rows in front of Sam, it was 2 rows infront. His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Where did the compassionate farmer allow the heifer to reside during her last days? Choices:  A: cattle ranch B: countryside C: grocery store D: slaughterhouse E: dairy farm<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Input 2: Which of the following numbers is 1 billion fewer than 3,500,000,003? Choices: 1. 3,499,999,997 2. 299,998,234 3. 1,499,333,111 4. 3,000,599,950 5. 3,400,009,000<n><n>### Response 2: 1<n><n>### Input3: Which is greater? 28 percent 6 percent 50 percent Choices: 1) A 2. 6 3. 50 4. 48 5. 44 6. 42<n><n>### Response3: E<n><n>### Question: Write a python program that answers the following multiple choice question:<n><n>### Task:<n>1. Zach bought the bike on the same day as his baby-sitting job. How much money did Zach earn during his job baby-sitting?<n>3. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Lilly owns the only kosher deli in the area. Choices:  A: teach B: cost money C: do work D: be productive E: help people<n><n>### Response:		The only choice that makes sense here is choice D, and it makes sense that all those cubicles in an office would all be used for productive purposes.<n><n>### Input :There are many cubicles. In the office? Choices:  (true) B: (true) C: (true) D: (false) E: (false)<n><n>### Response :(B)<n><n>### Input :(4+4+3)* (3+3)+ (3-3)+ (5+5+2)<n><n>### Instructions Add the following to correctly solve this equation. A: 84 B: 85 C: 86 D: 89<n><n>### Response (A)<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>### The steps to the equation were:<n><n>0 => 4 + 4 + 3(3) => 84 => 4 * 3 => 32<n><n>Next:<n><n>85 => 85 + 32 => 85 + (5)(5+2) => 85 +7 => 92<n><n><n>The last two steps are redundant.<n><n>### Exercise:<n><n>

Choices:  A: run programs B: play games C: control model D: power down E: reason exists<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answers:  B<n><n><n>### Instructions:<n>In this section, you will write a set of lines of code that will handle specific situations by implementing the instruction requests.<n><n>### Task:<n>### Write a program, where on the input line you will calculate the salary of the employee and on the second, and so on up to the fifth input line indicate how much of it should transfer to the account of the company. If not enough of the salary has been transferred to the account of the employee, transfer the amount of difference.<n>### Output:<n>At the end of the program, there should be a counter for the number of salaries that come out to the number specified by the input parameters.<n>### Example test cases<n>### Input:Salary of the employee, and how much of it should be transferred to the account of company<n>### Output: counter<n>### 12345,1<n>### 16567,5<n>### 31425,6<n><n>### Demonication:<n><img src="images/demo.jpg" width="700" height="400" alt="Demonstration" /><n><n>### Note:<n>Salary of the employee and how much of it is transferred to the account should be inputted in 4 lines, 3 lines respectively.<n><n>### Expected solution:<n>```<n>var t=$("#task").val();<n>var counter = 0;<n>for(var i=1; i<=t; i++){<n><n>    var f = $("#fr"+i).val();<n>    var c = $("#c"+i).val();    <n>    var fc = f - (f*c/100);  <n>    $("#salary").append((((salary)*100 - fc).toFixed(2)).replace(/(\.\d{1})((\d{3})+)/g, '$1,$2'));<n>    <n><n>    if(fc <=0){<n>       $("#error").append("Insufficent to the company account has not been transferred!\n");<n>    }<n><n>    var n=$("#n").val();<n>    n = Math.floor(n*fc/100);<n>    n--;<n>    $("#account").append(((n * 100

He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. Choices:  A: orgasm B: cum C: naked D: in bed E: wearing his birthday suit<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>#### Answer: E<n><n>Input:  How many times more did you save this month than you spent?  <n>Answer: 2<n><n>    **If (salary < 10000);**<n>    {<n> 	if ( (monthly_spend < 2000) or (monthly_deposit < 300) )<n>    	{<n>    		if (monthly_dep < monthly_spend)<n>                monthly_deposit = 1000<n>    	}<n><n>    	if (monthlyspend > 0)<n>    		monthly_save = monthly_spend - monthly_dep<n>      <n>    printf("$%.2f \n",monthly_dep)<n>    printf("$%.*f \n",3,monthly_save)  <n>    printf("You can $%.2f more next month.\n",-(2 * monthly_spend)) <n>    <n>    printf("For your sake, you should go $%.2f under this month.\n",-(monthly_deposite));<n>    printf("Good luck. \n");<n>    }<n>    <n><n>### Demostration - Complete the following task (be sure to include the prompts to the tester).<n><n>```python<n><n>### Instructions: Answer each statement or question. Rufus rides his motorcycle to the supermarket.  The supermarket is on the opposite side of the city from Rufus‚Äôs house.  After he leaves his motorcycle to buy groceries, he will take a shortcut across a grassy field between the homes on Dale Street.  Each house is 500 meters away from the next.  He‚Äôll make his way to one house on each street and he‚Äôll cross this field 11 times.  There are 380 houses on the eight streets.  How many different streets does Rufus visit in order to reach the supermarket?<n><n>### Answer:<n>Four <n><n>### Question Two:<n><n>### Sarah‚Äôs brother owns a bakery.  He owns 30 loaves of bread to be sold.  His bakery is open on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays.  On Tuesdays, he receives shipments of 8 loaves from the bakery that makes his bread and he sells 3 loaves that day.  On Thursdays, he receives shipment of 12 loaves and Sarah, his assistant, helps him to sell 6 loaves that day. He sells the remaining 5 loaves the following Saturday. How many loaves does he have when he gets 2 shipments of 8?<n><n>###Answer:<n>###Instruction:<n><n>###Write a response that uses a command to direct another program object that was started via a `start()` function.<n><n>## Instructions:Write a program  that uses a loop to print the days of week using an `on()` function. <n><n>## Answer 1:<n>```<n><n>on(name = "day of week")<n>if(hour > 3 and hour < 9)<n>	print("Monday")<n>else<n>	print("Tuesday")<n>end

If this is your 18th month on your plan, how much data do you use in total? Choices: A: 973152MB B: 973004MB C: 973484MB D: 973659MB<n><n>### Response :Data transfer is measured in bytes or bits. 1024 bytes equals 1 Kilobyte (Kb). 1000 Kilobytes equals 1 megabyte (MB). 100,000 megabytes equals 1 gigabyte (GB). Therefore, you use about 1 GB per 18 months.<n><n>### Comments<n>- If someone asks a question, they usually expect an answer. (The second operation will be the sum of the digits).<n><n>### Demands 1 & 2 with justification<n><n>**Demand 1**<n><n>> If a, b and c are consecutive odd numbers, what is the value of (a + b + c + 1) + (a + b + 10)?<n><n>In order to solve this problem, we have to assume that the following pattern is being reproduced:<n>```<n>a : b : c :  (a + b +c) + (a +10)<n>```<n>This means that the right hand side of the sequence in the pattern repeats and thus:<n>```<n>13 : 17 : 19 :  (13 + 17 + 19) + (13 +

Choices: A: television B: a dumpster C: a landfill D: a fox news E: a trashcan<n><n>```py<n>#!/usr/bin/python3<n># -*- coding: utf-8 -*-<n><n>def get_tv_channel_and_program_info_for_a_date():<n>    """<n>    You are given a datetime.datetime object representing the current date,<n>    and an array of strings representing channels on which the TV program(s) can<n>    be viewed. The string represents the format of a programming line, including time<n>    of the program (e.g. "4:30 PM"). The input to this function is the same for every<n>    call, but you will find different entries in the output. The output consists<n>    of lines like "FOX 11 PM - 12 AM: 'The Simpsons'".<n>    """<n><n>    def split(text,delim):<n>        result = []<n>        for c in [c for c in text if not c.isdigit()]:<n>            result.append(c)<n>        if delim!= '' :<n>            result.append(' ')<n>        return result<n>    # Example input: "2020-06-25 23:43:00 PDT PBS PBS HDTV Fox"<n>    result = ''<n>    # We can extract the date using the date/time format<n>    current_date_part,current_time = datetime.datetime.strptime(get_date_to_current_datetime().strftime("%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S %z"), '%Y-%m-%d.%H:%M:%S.%z').split()<n>    <n>    # We can split the input in to parts and use the delimiters and values given by the user<n>    delims,parts = split(current_date_part,':')<n>    # extract the delimeters given by the user.<n>    hours=[]<n>    minutes=[]<n>    if delims[1]=="" : # If they didnt use the : to delimit the hours and minutes, then we can use the split function above<n>        hours = ["08","09","10","11"]

Therefore, "c" <n><n></ul><n><ul><li><n>D: hotel :</li><n><n><ul><n>Hotels are expensive and usually have few room amenities in them. They <n>are in cities.  Thus c is the correct answer.<n></ul></ul><n><li>:<li><code>:</code></li><li><n>E: motel :</li><n>Motels are a  place usually located out side of town or out of the city.  Motels <n>provide few amenities and are usually much cheaper than hotels. Therefore, "e" is the <n>correct alternative.<n><n></ul><ul><li><code>:</li></ul><n></ul>

How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. Choices: a: 3 b: 0 c: 6 d: 30<n>### Response: A is correct.<n>### Input What is 9 less than 46? Choices: a 4 7 b. 1 3 c. 0 1 d. -1 4<n>### Response: D is correct.<n>## <n>##   --------------------------------------------<n>### Input:<n>--- A woman bought 5 sticks of butter and her sister bought 8 sticks of butter.<n>--- The woman and her sister each ate 4 sticks.<n>--- Each of their children ate 2 sticks.<n>--- The remaining butter was divided among the grandchildren.<n>--- The grandchildren each ate 54 tablespoons of butter.<n>### Demonstraion<n>--- What were the number of total sticks of butter?<n>#### Answer: There are 36 sticks of butter<n>--- What was the number of total tablespoons of butternut squash?<n>--- What was the grandchildren's portion in sticks and tablespoons?<n>--- Is it possible for the grandchildren to eat more than 54 tablespoon of butter?<n>--- What would be the rest after dividing and the grandchildren eat all the 54 tablespouns of butter?<n><n>### The first number represents the number of sticks of butter bought by: the woman | her sister | both woman and sister | nobody | the grandchildren<n><n>> -------------<n>The second number represents the number of tablespoons of buttermilk each:  woman ate| ate her sister| ate herself | the two women as a family<n><n>> -------------	<n>The third number represents the number of  tablespoons butter each:  the woman's child ate| the sister's child ate | both children at the table<n><n>> -----------------<n>The fourth number represents the remaining  tablespoons of buttered squash:  remaining in the
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:The mother was worried about all the spills, so she bought a rug for under the what? Choices:  A: persia B: table C: living room D: house E: desk<n><n>### Response:		<n>If the mother was worried about the spills she should have gotten a rug!

Choices:  A: sum B: likeness C: alike D: sameness E: similarity<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question, based on the input.<n><n>### In order to answer the question, we must find the absolute value or "distance" between numbers that are similar, but not equal.<n><n>### Example, find the absolute value between  2 and 5<n><n><n>### Solution<n><n>![](https://docs.google.com/drawings/current/d/149q-wfUWZJ-U_EJl66Xu6sD4K7i5H5LBpNq9o44B50c/edit?usp=sharing)<n><n>### Demnstration: <n>Input: 2 is similar to 5 but they are not the same.  This is because 2 - 5 is negative and an example of "distance:2:5 would be as follows: |2-5| =2-(-5) =2+5 = 3<n><n>### Input <n><n>2 is similar to 2 but they are not the sum <n><n>### Demostration 2:<n> ![](https://docs.wixstatic.com/ugd/4e54b8_ba99547703854112abf741399a706c87.png)<n><n>5 is similar to 1 but they are not the distance between two numbers<n><n>### Demstration: <n><n>Input: <n><n>![](httpss://docs.wixsdstatic.com/ugdd/1e0eaa9_2fc492aaba384d3e971ff0c6e555d9a1.png)<n><n>## Instructions:<n><n>Answers the following multiple choice question based on the input. In order to answer the<n>question, we must find the sum between numbers that are similar.<n><n>## Demonstration: <n>Example: Find the sum between 12 and 19 in the following steps:<n><n>1. Subtract your smallest number of each set from your biggest number: 12-1<n><n>2. Calculate the sum between the two remaining numbers: 12+13+14

How much will the cone cost?<n>### Response A:<n>$18<n>### Response B:<n>$95<n>### Response C:<n>$140<n>### Response D:<n>$17<n>### Input<n>A caterpillar can grow up to 100 times it's size. If it begins at size 10 and grows at a constant rate, but still has to pass through 100 positions on the size scale, how long will it take for the caterpillar to emerge as a butterfly?<n><n>### Response<n>I don't know.<n><n>### Input A:<n>Five more than 1/2<n>### Response B<n>3<n><n>### Input B:<n>Kimberly's school has 5 classes all teaching subjects like math, history, and science. How many students are in each class?<n>### Response B'<n>6<n><n>### Input C:<n>121212<n>### Response C<n>1312121<n><n>### Input D:<n>1<n>### Response D<n>2<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following true or false questions.<n>### A) It is possible to take 23 more than 2 times 102.<n>### B) 5 people have the same birthday as Kim<n>### C) I am right handed<n>### D) Sarah and Sarah are siblings<n>### E) 19 is equal to 19<n>### F) George did not buy a hat<n>### G) 5 is the same as 5<n>### H) 7 is divisible by 3<n>
