Choices:  A: waterfalls B: underwater C: beach D: surface of earth E: river<n><n>### Response:		E<n>The above instruction provides an example of calculating a fractional unit. The first step would be to recognize the denominator is an even base number, 100.  <n>Second, you would divide 1 by the denominator, since the numerator (the part before the division sign) is the number of items you are trying to determine relative to the denominator (the part after the division sign). If you do not know how to divide 1 to determine remainder, you could use the division algorithm. A helpful hint is that 1 / 1 equals 1 (1 remainder).<n><n>After determining 1 out of every 3 is covered by the water, you would need to find the percentage of what's covered to determine the answer. Since the fraction "one third" equals 1/3, you could use percentages to calculate what percentage of 100 is covered by the water.   <n><n>### Input :The average age in a class is 15. The age of a student who is in that class is 10. Is the age of a student greater or less than the average age? Choices: A: Less than   B: Greater than C: Between<n><n>### Response :B<n>The student is greater than the average age.<n><n>### Input You have 5 socks. If you have 3 blue and 2 pink, how can you make the following true with only the socks you have:?  1. You have at least 3 blue and at least 3 pink.  <n>  2. You have at least the same  number of blue as you do pink.  <n>Choices:  A: Put on a blue sock and a pink sock at the same time. B: Pair up and trade socks.  <n><n>### Response  :B<n>You could take a pink sock, and then put on one of the blue socks as seen above in scenario 2. From that, you would end up losing one set of blue and the same number of pink.<n><n>###Input:You have two shirts and four pairs of pants. Choices:  A: conduct trial B: arrest C: bring in verdict D: pass sentence E: serve justice<n><n>### Response:		 E<n><n>### Explanation: <n>During the process an officer may have to present evidence to the arrest warrant. When presented, evidence must be supported with an arrest warrant. The officer must then call a witness to the jury. If the witness does not come for a jury, a case will not go to trial. The judge, after hearing the testimony of the witness, will either accept the testimony as true and convict the defendant. If the judge is not comfortable with the testimony, he will not accept it and release the defendant. A jury will decide if the defendant is guilty or not. For example, if the testimony of a witness shows that the defendant had committed a crime such that he possessed a gun or a knife, a jury can convict the suspect and he will be sentenced to prison <n><n>### What should a player do when he is not sure if he is supposed to take the ball to the left or right?<n><n>### Experiment:Try this yourself<n>### Answer:A<n><n>### Exploration:The rules of soccer are clear so as long as a player takes the ball in the right direction, he will be able to play and score. But I noticed that there are many instances where players get confused whether to take the ball to left or right when he is being tackled so that they can have the ball out of the playing field.

How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What would humans do when their legs are tired? Choices:  A: ghost town B: third world country C: human body D: rug E: hospital<n><n>### Response:		Ghost town (B)<n><n>Detailed Solution:<n><n>We know that the correct response can be A, B, C, D, or E. First, we eliminate the choices that are not correct responses. We know that <n><n>Disease isn't spread in C because it exists inside us. If it was inside us, it wouldn't be spreading, so we know C is not the correct answer.<n><n>Similarly, we also know that D and E are not correct because the human body is not a ghost town. There are people, so it cannot be a ghost town.<n><n>Now, we are left with the 4 remaining choices: A, B, D, and E. We first focus on A and B because they are opposite choices, meaning that if choice A is correct, then choice B must be incorrect.<n><n>Further, we notice that in choice A, disease can be spread, but since disease is spread there, it must be in a ghost town. Therefore, disease can only be spread but must definitely not exist there.<n><n>On the other hand, choice B states that disease exists in the ghost town but can be spread. It must exist in a ghost town since disease cannot exist anywhere apart from a ghost town. However, it can also be spread, which suggests that the disease cannot be spread in B. We conclude that A must be the correct choice.<n><n>### Input : There are 30 girls in my class. I have 7 pears. Each pear feeds 3 people. How many people can I feed with my pear?<n><n>### Demostration :<n><n>Input: 2/3+1=1 1/3+1=-1 1/3-1/3=-1/3 2/3-1=-1/3 <n><n>### Solution:<n>20+11=31    <n>20-11=9    <n>20-9=11    <n>9-9=0    <n>0-3=3    <n>3-3=0    <n>-3/-3=-1/3<n><n>### Input There are 6 men and 4 women on the committee. How many of each are there?<n><n>### Solution<n><n>1.Count up 1 to 11<n><n>2.Count up 11 twice

If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. Choices:  A: feel pleasure B: look attractive C: compliments D: interesting experiences E: joy<n><n>### Response:		A or B or C or D or E<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following questions in a detailed response.<n><n>### Question 1:Is "Jingle Bell Rock" by Bobby Helms a holiday song?<n><n>### Question2:Explain the difference between the following vocabulary pairs.<n><n>*   "Gross and Fine motor skills"<n><n>*   "A, B, C"<n><n>*   A) "Cool, and Charming"<n><n>*   B) "Vivacious, and Bland"    <n><n>### Sample Exam Question:Explain why Mary must have more than $70 after she earns her weekly allowance.<n><n>### Response<n><n>#### Mary's Weekly Allowance<n><n>When a holiday occurs, Mary makes about $10 more at her part-time job. She has $50 left after buying new shoes. She has three hours to spend on her allowance and wants to save a little. She can only purchase things at a value of $20 or less to save 25%. She doesn't like to spend too much. Each pair costs $6, one jacket costs $50 and four pairs of socks cost $7. How many items can she buy at her family's store?<n><n>Mary wants to save 25% of the allowance or $5. She has $10 to spend, so she must calculate 0.25 * $10, which equals $2.50. She wants to buy items that are $20 or less because the sales tax is equal to 7.5%. If each pair costs $6, then 0.25 x 6 equals $1.50 in tax, so to save 25%, she subtract $1.50. As for the jacket and the socks, Mary can purchase two pairs of socks and four jackets. Her final cost with 25% off is equal to $1.75 + $2.50 + $24 = $29.25. Mary has a total of 6.5 hours to spend on her weekly allowance, so she has about $0.45 an hour to spend. Mary wants to purchase 6.5 / 2 / 1.75 = 3

If  they play piano then they play music  or another music through keyboard. The student can play piano if  they have piano or keyboard, but they can also play other instruments  because the instrument can be black and white.<n>

If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What should the bean bag chair sit on? Choices:  A: house B: den C: family room D: wood E: floor<n><n>### Response:		C house<n><n>### Input<n><n>What should the bean bag hug the cushion of? Choices: A: bed B: den C: house D: armchair E: floor<n><n><n>### Response<n><n>A D<n><n>### Input - Answer A and D<n><n>Josh bought a bag of M&Ms at the store for $ 3.65. There were 350 m&Ms in the bag. How much does each M&M cost?<n><n>### Response - 10:20<n><n>.65¬¢<n><n>Input:  The total value of the ticket is $550, what are the odds that the numbers on the ticket are in the range from 400 to 500?<n><n>Answer: 0.7618%<n><n>### Instructions:What is the 1st digit of the 3rd number written in the table?<n><n>### Demostration A - B C - D<n><n>3A+1B=C D=1<n><n>4 A - 1B = 3<n><n>5A - 2B = 4 C - 1D = 12B<n><n>6 A + 2B = 7 D -1C = 18B<n><n>7A -2B = 5 C -3D =24B<n><n>8A + 3B =.9 CD -.1 CB = 15B<n><n>### Demos<n><n>7 A - 2 B = 5<n><n>8 A + 3 B = 9<n><n>9C -.1 B = 11C<n><n>10C - 2B =12 CD<n><n>11 C - 2D = 2 A C<n><n>12 A -2D = 11<n><n>### Demstration<n><n>Add the last four numbers in column 3; 1, 4, 5 and 2. These are additions in column 4; add these four together to find the sum of the first four numbers in column 1; those numbers are 9.<n><n>

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. How much money did Mary make?<n><n>### Answer:<n>Mary made $440<n><n>### Explain Your Work:<n>The equation of the given problem:<n><n>| Units Sold Features | Price per Unit Features | Total<n>| ---------------- | --------------- |:---:|<n>| 2 | $20 and $40 | $160 |<n>| 10 | $20 and 40 | $1120 |<n>| 20 | $50 and 12 | $660 |<n>| Total | $ | |<n><n><n><n>### Question (answer: 64):<n>Input: Tom‚Äôs mom gave Tom $30. He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Which long saga will we be watching on tonight's program? Choices:  A: concert B: opera C: theater D: take class E: television<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```<n>The concert will be watched because it's concert and there's a big singer.<n>```<n><n>### Example:<n><n>```<n>Question:<n>> Your mother-in-law is coming for a visit next Saturday. She's arriving at 11:00am and leaving Monday morning. You're planning an evening dinner party at 6:00pm. Is there enough time for her to visit? Please choose one of the following.<n>><n>A  Yes, there will be time<n>B  No, there won't be time<n>C  Undecided<n><n>Your response:<n>><n>A<n>```<n>

He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Where would you put silverware once they've dried, but you're not ready to use them. Choices:  A: table B: restaurant C: cupboard D: kitchen E: sink<n><n>### Response:		<n>- A: table<n>    <n>- B: restaurant<n>    <n>- C: cupboard<n>    <n>- D: kitchen<n><n>The answer, "C" doesn't make sense...<n><n>---<n><n>### Input2: Write a response to the description.<n><n>### Response2:<n><n>Answer:<n>My answer doesn't match with the actual answer: D: kitchen which is also wrong. But if you remove one more D from the question, then you will have D: table as the answer. It can be found by removing one more D.<n><n>---<n>

Answer: Always washing hands before eating helps prevent diseases(A: D).<n><n><n><!-- #region 0 <n><n>---><n><n>### Instructions:Provide an alternate response or a correct alternative interpretation to at least one word choice in the body of the instructions.<n><n>### Demo<n><n>Instruction:Answer the following sentence prompts.<n><n>Demonstration:<n><n>Choose the correct phrasal verb that completes the sentence.<n><n>Tony saw the movie last night. __________________ was good enough he saw it two times.<n><n>Correct answer: Tony was good enough to see the movie two times.<n><n>Answer: Tony was good enough that he saw the movie two times.  He knew the plot, and found little value in watching it a second time.<n><n>Choose the alternative verb form that best matches the sentence given.<n><n>Making up for missing yesterday's class, Sherman has been catching up on ___________________ the work he's missed.<n><n>Correct answers: making up or catching up<n><n>Answer: catching up on<n><n><n>---<n><h4 id="493615"><n>## Test<n></h4><n><n>### Test:<n><h2 id="495597"><n>1.<n></h2><n><n>Choose the response that is most similar and best fits the question.<n><n><n>| Questions | Answers |<n>|----------|----------|<n>| What do all living things need? |<n>| | <n>| _______ |<n>| ______. |<n>| Oxygen |<n>| Food |<n>| |<n>| |<n><n><n><n>Answer: Questions |  Answers<n>------------ | -------------<n> What do all living things | need? *<n><n>Answer: _______<n> Oxygen<n><n>| |<n>| <n>What do all living things need to live? |<n>|<n>|<n><n><n>| Question | Answer |<n>| ------- | ------- |<n>| What do all | A. living |<n>| | B. living |<n>| ____ | C. breathing |<n>| C. breathing<n><n>|<n>

A mistake sometimes happens when the player is playing the game, but some happen because of the pitcher throwing the ball to a player and it gets to another player by accident. It is all about doing your best.  <n><n><n>During the game each team has 9 players in the field. They have one set of players on offense that play close to the bases (a base ball), and the other team is on defense so they play close to the pitcher‚Äôs (base ball pitcher) box. A team scores by a player hitting the ball and getting to the bases before two other people on the field can tag him out, but if they get to all of the bases before getting all of them tagged it is considered a double or triple, if they get a homerun they will get 4 runs for the same batter, so the team that scores the most runs wins the game.<n><n> <n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n> <n>

Choices:  A: eyes B: biology laboratory C: shower stall D: old cheese E: decaying matter<n><n>### Response:		C: shower stalls<n><n>```<n><n># The code below uses the get_input() method to get the question and then using the split() method, that I have defined with the delimeter of " ", to break the question and the answer into two parts.<n><n>def get_input():<n>    return input('Please enter a question that you are looking for. Press enter when you are done.'<n>)<n>    question = get_input()<n>    question = question.split(' ')<n>    question[0]=question[0][0:question[0].count(' ')+1]<n>    answer=question[1]<n>return question,answer<n>						<n># The question and answers are split using the split() method. The split() method takes in a string and returns a list. It also takes in a delimeter, in this case the string, and a second argument, that being a string, to determine what character to split at. The second argument must come after the comma, (,) and be put into quotation marks so that it knows that it is a string and not anything.<n>def split (string,delimeter):<n>delimeter=delimeter.lstrip(delimeter)<n>delimeter=delimer.rstrip(delimeter)	<n>delimeter=deliemter.strip(delimeter) <n>delimter=delimeter[1:len(delember)].lstrip(delimeter).rstrip(delimeter).strip(delimeter)  <n>answer = delimeter[:-1]+delimeter[:-1]<n>return answer<n>	<n>#The logic behind the code starts with the variable for question. I am using string, but I could use any data type, I just thought it would be easier and less confusing. I then take the input with the get_input()method and return it as a string with the variable question. I then take the delimeter, in this question and answer it comes down to the space character, and I set it as the delimiter. I then go through the string and split at every space character and create the list question[0] and leave the last character. The question and answer is then returned in a list of 1x2. I then take each of those into a variable which, in this case is question and answer. I then take each variable and push the variable onto a list and then store both of the variables in an
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Where would you find a metal rod in most people's preferred method of transportation? How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:The drug kingpin told his man to run errands, this was code to go to all the dealers to do what they had? Choices:  A: park B: make time for C: receive instructions D: take money E: leave work<n><n>### Response:		A: park<n><n>### Explanation:<n>If "errands" refers to "go to all the dealers" then "code" refers to "to do what they have" as each errand requires to do something.<n>

If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What is the only was to recover from exhaustion? Choices:  A: mediate B: have rest C: stay in bed D: run out of steam E: go to sleep<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Instructions:Complete the task.<n><n>| 8 | + |<n>|-  |+|<n>|+ |+ |<n>|+ |+  |<n>|9 |+ |<n>|-- |+  |<n>+ |+ |<n>-- |+ |<n>| 2 | +  |<n>+ |--  |<n>| 9+ | + |<n>+ | +  |<n>|+  | +  |<n><n>### Input answer: (10 x + 4)(8 x + 3)<n><n>### Instuction:What is 5/6 times 3/5?<n><n>### Demnstration:<n>5/6 * 3/5 = 6/5<n><n><n>### Instituctions:<n>Write an expression that is equivalent to 5/6 x 5/3<n><n>#Exercise 2<n>### Instruction 1:<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>### Instution B:<n>What is the product of <n><n>### Instutution 2:<n><n>### Deletion:<n><n>### Exercise 3 <n><n>### Interlude 1:<n><n>In this task, we want to read the <n><n>### Excercise 5:<n>You write a conditional expression of <n><n><n>### Exam 6:<n><n>### Intermezzo 7:<n><n>### Problem 8:<n><n>### Exit 8:<n><n>A: Mediate B: Have rest C: Stay in bed D: Run out of steam E: Go to sleep<n><n>## Instructions:Write a conditional expression for each statement. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What group of musicians will include someone playing the cello? Choices:  A: ocean B: symphony C: band D: music store E: music shop<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: E: music shop<n>

We use the following:<n>- In the first row, we use one large sticker + two stickers of small.<n>- In the second row, we use one sticker, two times small one.<n>- In the third row, we use one medium and the same small sticker two times.<n>- In the fourth row, we use both large and medium and same small sticker.<n><n>#### Part II:<n>The sum of numbers in each set.<n><n><n><n>### Part III:<n>Follow the directions for each question.<n>

It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Sally lost her kite because she wasn't careful.  She thought that there was more string on the spool, but it slipped out of her fingers when she reached the what?. Choices:  A: child's hand B: the last straw C: hobby shop D: end of line E: toy store<n><n>### Response:		<n>A. End of line<n><n>### InputSelena's birthday is in 4 weeks from today.  She is going to be celebrating by having the what? Choices A:  Birthday cake B:  Balon C:  Strawberry D:  Party E:  Cupcake<n><n>### Response<n><n>A. Party<n><n>### InstTiffany won the first game 142 to 128 and won the second game 127 to 132. She scored more points in the second game.  What is the difference in points that she is 6 for in her final score?<n><n>### Response <n>If we subtract 127 (bottom) from 142 (top) we get 14 which is less than 6<n><n>### InstSam has 2 dogs and 3 cats.  If the ratio of dogs to cats is 5 to 4, what is the ratio of cats and dogs to 5 to 3?<n><n>### InstWendy's dog is running and 27 mph.  The dog's brother is jogging 2.5 mph slower than Wendy.  How fast is the dog's brother running?<n><n>### Res <n>If we take the difference between 27 and the slower brother we get 24.5 which is 4.5 less than 28 (the smaller number from 27 and the smaller number from 2.5)<n><n>### InstThere are 16 pancakes, 21 muffins, 15 slices of bread, 17 slices of bacon, 50 peaches and 31 apples.  Each family member can only take 2 pancakes and 2 peaches and they must divide in an even manner. How much food can they take, in each, of the remaining foods?<n><n>### InstrSally is at a museum. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:East coast areas such as Florida are found where? Choices:  A: florida B: denmark C: united states D: map E: california<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n><n>

Can you explain to her how to convert Celcius to Fahrenheit?  Input: 6 Celcius  Output: 43 Fahrenheit<n><n>### Response<n><n>Tanya, I see that Celsius and Fahrenheit have to be different. In other words if it is 6 then it must be 29. 6 Celsius converts to 29 Fahrenheit for 29 Fahrenheitt = 29*(9/5)+32.<n><n>### Input <n><n>I found these shapes out on these paper. I need to know how to write their equations.  Input: the left side is (4x)+(4x+1)+2  Output: 2<n><n>### Response <n><n>The left side of the paper you wrote should look like this 2x^2+(4x+1)x=.  Then subtract 2 from both sides and that gives .  If you square both sides and add 2 from the left side then that equals 4x' so your final solution is (4x'+2).

What is the total amount Mary has earned working at the store?<n>Answer: $4,750<n><n>### Instudcation:<n><n>### Instrection:<n>Input: What is the length of a car if it is 8 yards long and drives at 20 yards per hour?<n>Answer: Yard<n>### Insturctions Answer a Multiple Choices Question<n><n>### Input<n>What is an apple‚Äôs favorite musical instrument?<n>Answer: Piano<n><n>### Insturction:<n>What is a good thing that happens to an egg when it gets out of a carton?<n>Answer: It's the beginning of a great day!<n><n>### Instution:<n>Sonya is playing soccer and scoring goals using a baseball bat. (Source: https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/347975/if-woman-a-is-twice-as-likely-to-achieve-an-honorable-mention-as-woman-b-and)<n><n>### Demostration(s) of the problem<n><n>### I know this:<n><n>### My Question:<n>  Which of following is equivalent?<n><n>```<n>   2^(1/2)= 2*0.5<n>   2^(1/(2*33)) = 2*0.059375<n><n>   10^(1/2)=10*0.5<n>  10^(1/(10*33)) =  2^(1/(100))<n><n>   100^(1/2) =100*0.5 = 50<n>   100^((1/(10*23)) = 5 // or 5/23?<n>```<n>

Choices:  A: gas stations B: city C: london D: train station E: airport<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input -:1-2-1-1 3-2-5-2 4-1-4-2 5-2-1-4 6-1-4-5 <n>### Output:<n>Total - 35 (if wrong continue try one more time this problem)<n><n>### Input 100 -150 --------20 <n>### Output :<n>Total 150 (if wrong check another)<n><n>### 100/2=50<n><n>### 20*2=40<n><n>### Total 90<n><n>### Task :<n><n>### Write a program that counts how many positive and how many negative integers are given in one number.<n><n>### Sample Input:9 8 5 1 4 <n><n>### Sample Output:<n>Positive 3<n><n>Negative 2<n><n>### Sample Solution:<n><n>```<n>function main() {<n>  var n, aString<n>  readInt(n);<n>  n = n.split(" ")<n>  let t = 0;<n>  for (let i = 0; i < n.length; i++) {<n>    aString = n[i]<n>    if (aString > 0) {<n>      t += +aString<n>    } else {<n>      t = -t<n>    }<n>  }<n>  console.log(t > 0? "Positive " + t : "Negative " + t)<n>}<n><n>function readInt(n) {<n>  console.log("Enter number")<n>  let n1 = readLine()<n>  n = null<n>  if (n1!== null && n1.trim()!== "") {<n>    n = parseInt(n1)<n>  } else {<n>    console.log("Please enter valid number")<n>  }<n>}<n>```<n><n>### If you write it in HackerRank, what kind of score would you give yourself?<n><n>### If the solution is HackerRank solution, what kind of improvement would you suggest to the author?

His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:How might a person address someone who is leaving? Choices:  A: further cause B: wave goodbye C: attempt suicide D: insulting them E: thank god<n><n>### Response:		C: attempt suicide<n><n>### Input-Answer<n>Input: If she spends $15 on gum and uses 5 gum, what percent of her money is spent on gum?<n>Input:If 20 percent of a number is 24, what percent of 100 is 32?<n>Output: 2 percent<n><n>Answer: % = (2 of 20 / 100) x 100 = 2/20 x 100<n><n>Input:I lost my phone and realized I didn't have its number. I need to get my number back, what equation best represents this.? <n><n>Answer: We want to find the unknown variable x. (The variable x is the number that we know but doesn't know how much it is). Since we know the two sides of the equation, x can be any number between those two sides. So 10-x = (10 - 10) 10 = 0 and  x= 10. <n><n>Input: If you know that the area of a square is 25, what is the area of a rectangle if 4 times its width is equal to 7 times its height? <n><n>Answer : 25*7 (the area of the rectangle)/(14*(4*2) (4 is the width of the rectangle and so 4*2 would represent the rectangle being doubled to show its width was 8.)<n><n>Input:If x equals 5 less than 3 times y, find x.<n><n>Answer: x = 5 -(3x)<n><n>Input:A person is running to 3 different destinations, 10 miles per hour from her home to the train station, 15 miles per hour to the park, and 9 miles per hour at the park from where she is heading to the grocery store. She reaches her destinations in a 3.5 minute, 7 minute, and 40 minute, respectively. What is the distance of the journey?<n><n>Answer: You will have to use the formula for the distance to solve for the distance.<n>S = d * t<n>The distance travelled from Home to the Train station, Park, and Grocery Store is 35 miles.<n>The distance travelled to the Train Station, Park and back to the

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Someone lacking immortality will one day be? Choices:  A: kick the bucket B: mortal C: dead D: can die E: dying<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>If someone lacks immortality, he might be able to die or become mortal.<n><n>### Input and Response:<n><n>```<n>Jim's friend John has 44 marbles. John is older than Jim. If John gave away 14 marbles to Jim, how many marbles did John have left?<n>Answer choice: 40<n>```<n>```<n>John has 44 marbols and gave away 14 to Jim.<n>If Jim has 14 marbols and John is older then him.<n>Jam has 7 and Johns marbles are 41.<n>Answer is 41.<n>John gave away 14, so 41 - 14 = 27.<n><n>John has 27 marbles<n><n>```<n>

Try different programming languages until you think you have a correct answer. Save your progress with the **[submit_answer](https://github.com/s-a-m-w/Javapro-Assitant/tree/master/Javascript/Javascript_Languages/Javascript_Programming_Assistant/src/submit/submit_answer.js)** file.<n><n>### Question 1<n><n>### Question Description<n>You have a window, that has a screen of dimensions `screenHeight` and `screenWidth` that can be represented by two integers. On the screen there is a fox which resides in the center of the screen `screenPosition` and that can be represented by a point. A point can be represented as a pair of integers. If the left coordinate of the point is the first integer then the right coordinate of the same point is the second integer. The fox does not want to step out of bounds on the screen.<n><n>Given the coordinates of the center of the screen and your dimensions of the screen, determine if the fox could exist on the screen with the given conditions.<n>**Explanation:**<n>```<n>For the following values:<n>screenHeight=4,screenWidth=4<n>screenPosition={1,2},screenWidth=4<n>Then the fox could exist as such:<n>screenPosition={1+1,2+2}={2,4}<n>screenPosition={-1,2},screenHeight=4<n>Then the case where the fox couldn't exist:<n>screenPosition={-3,2},screenHeight/2=2<n>```<n><n>**Input:**<n>```<n>screenHeight = 4<n>screenWidth = 4<n>screenPosition = {1,2}<n>```<n><n>**Output:**<n>```<n>True<n>```<n><n>### Question Examples<n>#### Solution 1<n>We'll define an array `array` and a function `add` to increment the element of the array by one, then return the updated array.<n>```html<n><script type="text/javascript"src="index.js"></script><n>function add(array){<n>  <n>  return [...array,1]<n>}<n>Array(2).push(3) is an error<n>```<n>

If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:If an animal is tired, what is it likely to do? Choices:  A: bite B: lie down C: keep alive D: need to eat E: go to sleep<n><n>### Response:		B<n>### Instruction 2:<n>Input: What is the square root of X^2?<n>Input: Answer: What is the square of X^3?<n><n>Input: The area of the pond is 4.6 m2, find the length and width of the pond.<n>Answer: 2.3 m<n><n>Input: An isosceles triangle has 2 equal sides. What is the longest side?<n>Input: The base of a right triangle is twice the width, what is the height?<n>Input: John has a collection of 51 sticks of various lengths. (50 ‚Äì 30 = 20. 90 ‚Äì 30 is 60)<n>Input: Choose another number between 30 and 70. I will add 30 degrees to that number. What number will the result be? Round your answer to ten thousandths. (70 + 30 is 100)<n><n>###Instrucion 4:<n>Input: Choice B<n>Input: Choice C<n><n>Input: Choice A<n><n>Input: Choose the number that can be formed from the letters in ‚Äúcereal‚Äù. For example, "that guy is the worst father a kid could wish for."<n><n>### Some more _____ [BLANKS]!<n><n>### An emotion that is usually expressed as happiness about something good.<n><n>### As much as possible.<n><n>### Wear and tear on shoes, bags, or clothing, usually caused by walking on concrete.<n><n>### All at once (at every moment of time).<n><n>### Very happy.<n><n>### "_____ [BLANTS]: An emotion that is when you wish something bad

Multiple Choice](https://leetcode.com<n>>.com/problems/multiple-choice/)<n><n>### Input<n>Tom wants to buy his favorite type of ice cream, which comes in three different flavors: vanilla, strawberry and chocolate, and it's priced at \$3, \$2, and \$1, respectively. He wants to buy an ice cream cone, and his budget is \$10. There are several ice cream shops, and each shop has different prices:<n><n>* Shop #1 sells ice cream for \$2 cheaper than Shop #2 and \$1 cheaper than Shop#3.<n>* Shop #2 sells ice cream of the same cost as Shop #3<n>* All ice cream is sold at the same price at Shop #4<n><n>Note that this question uses three values, each representing a different ice coffee shop. All ice cream shops have the same prices, such that the cost of the ices cream is \$3, \$2 and \$1 for the shops from left to right.<n>Tom wants to choose either the vanilla or strawberry ice cream cone, each at the cost of \$10. He has already spent \$4 at the shop with the highest price before buying his favorite ice cream cone.<n>What is the minimum amount of money he must have on him before buying his favorite cone?<n><n>### Response<n>Ice cream shop name: 1,2,3,4<n>Flavor Price: 3,2,1<n>Answer: 3 or the minimum amount is 10<n>To get the minimum amount you need to go to the cheapest ice cream shop and buy as many vanilla or straw or choc

Choices:  (A) Put all the clothes into his car, including those he would wear to the airport on his way to the date. (B) Put only the clothes he would wear to the date on and into a suitcase. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What would an adult man do to get ready for work? Choices:  A: dress herself B: shower C: dress himself D: drink beer E: drive train<n><n>### Response:		Choices:  A, B, C, B, A, B, B, B, A, A, A, D, A, A, C<n><n>### Instructions:Complete the math problems.15 - 2 =?2 - ___ =?6 - 1 = ___<n><n>### Demosntration:<n>Input: 15 - 2<n><n>Answer: 13<n><n>Input: 2 - ___<n><n>Answer: 0<n><n>Input: 6 - 1<n><n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Input - Choose: A. B. C. D. E.<n><n>### Response - Choose: A - C - C - D - A - C - B. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Simon bought a cow because he wanted to put it to work.   He didn't want any meat for it.  Where might Simon be taking the cow? Choices:  A: countryside B: city C: dairy farm D: butcher shop E: canada<n><n>### Response:		 I could be going on an adventure to explore the city, but I don't have any space for my cow in the city or on the countryside.   So Simon would go to the dairy farm because he doesn't want the cow for meat, but rather to work on a dairy farm.   That is why he bought his cow.<n><n>### Input:# The cat climbed the tree. The dog jumped into the cat's tree. Which animal got the highest on the tree?<n><n>### Response:# The dog got the highest on the dog's tree.   The dog was on the tree even before the cat climbed and it was when the dog jumped into the tree that the cat climbed as high as she could.<n><n>### Summary:  I solved three questions.  I used the word "so" to clarify for the reader an important fact in my statement.  I avoided using personal pronouns and plurals.<n><n>The instructions were clear and I could solve all of them.<n><n>

A sports car weighs 2000 pounds. Choices:  A: stress B: debate C: argument D: winning or losing E: tension<n><n>### Response:		<n>We can't exactly compare the amount of tension. It would be a matter of choice.<n><n>### Input A: What does the word ‚Äòcompete‚Äô mean?<n><n>### Response A:<n>to try to be successful in doing<n><n>### Input B: What does the phrase "competing on the field" mean?<n><n>## Response B:<n>To be competing against each other in an activity during practice<n><n>### Input C: What might happen if someone gets into an argument with their friend?<n><n>### Responses<n>1. If someone gets into an argument, it is possible that they can get into it with their friends if they have conflicting views.<n>2. It is possible that people will get into arguments. It is possible that two people competing might get into one of the possibilities.<n><n>### Question C: After people get into an argument with their best friend, could that cause some tension between them for a while?<n><n>### Answer<n><n>There are two possibilities of people getting into an argument. This is because there are two ways they can argue. The first reason being they might argue over something, the second being the fact that they had an argument.<n><n>### Answer D: How could people compete?<n><n>### What might be the first thing to get the competitors to begin competing, if it's not the case where they have already been competing? <n>### Could competitions be more about winning and losing? <n>### What would the competitors compete about, if it isn‚Äôt something physical,<n>### like going for a 100-meter run? <n>### Can you think of something to do instead of competing if you have only two people?<n><n>### Solution:There are two types of competition where the first example is called cooperative competition because competitors can share or divide the prize. The second type is called zero-sum competition where there can only be one winner. Since there are only two competitors, the competition will not be zero-sum competition.<n><n>### Can't you think of something else you can do instead of competing even if there are two competitors?<n>## Input: What might two people competing that we couldn't answer before.<n><n>### A: Which one of these things is possible for competing?<n><n>### B

Behavior that was not heretical.<n><n><n><n><n>### Input<n>The grocery store offers $2 off a case of eggs. A quart of milk is 25 cents off every gallon. A bag of potatoes is $7 off for each 5-pound bag. The manager at the grocery store found the sale prices. If her total was $9 less than twice what she paid, how much did each item cost?<n>Answer:<n>#### Case of Eggs<n>25 cents off each gallon = 11.5 cents off each quart so it is $7 off for a 5-pound of potatoes<n>$8.45 * 0.75 = $6.39 so the eggs are $6.61 each<n>Total was $3.28 * 3 = $9.74<n>So each case of eggs was $1 and they were $2 off.<n>#### Gallon of Milk<n>The gallon was $11.44 a gallon or $2 off that equals $9.44, $13.25 off for 2 gallons = $6.63. So the milks were $0.63 and they were $2.0 off for 2 gallon it is $1.96<n>The total of 2 was $3.92 so each case of milk was $1.96 each. <n><n>#### Potatoes<n>$13.25 * 0.98 = $13.05 which equals $12.58 so each case of potatoes was $12.50 each.<n><n>The total was $19.77 so each case of potatoe would be $6.21<n><n>#### Output<n>$6.39 * 6.21 = $39.21 each case of egg<n>$13.05 * 12.58 = $166.9 so each gallon of milk was $30.23 each<n>$12.58 * 2 = $25.16 so each bag of potatoes was $5 and the total was $30.42<n><n>So each item in case was $39.23 or $

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. He buys a hat for $10 and a pencil for $2. Then he buys four cookies. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Where would a Martian find the Indian Ocean? Choices:  A: asia B: southern hemisphere C: planet D: east E: earth<n><n>### Response:		<n>1.A<n>2.B<n>3.A<n>4.A<n>5.B<n>6.B<n>7.B<n>8.D<n>### Reference:<n>If you're looking for more math problems, you can try these math games: [50 Addition problems | 50 Subtraction problems](https://www.brilliant.org/practice/math/addition-and-subtraction/) - You can use these Brilliant lessons and other questions from the math games. I hope they help you to keep improving your mental math skills.<n><n>### Links:<n>- If you want a step by step explanation on how to solve mental math problems, you can check out the post written by Brilliant member [Nuha](https://forum.brilliant.org/@nuha). She writes that step by step explanations are her life. I agree with her that step by step explanaton can help you to learn more quickly.<n>- Mental Math and Brilliant - [mental math + Brilliant video tutorial](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XxCeLkHYnT8)* - Mental Math questions are great to practice on Brilliant, which can help you to solve complex problems.<n>

His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>Input: Josh‚Äôs mom gives him $20 to go shopping at the mall. If each cookie costs $1.25, how much money does Josh have left?<n>Answer: 3<n><n>Input: George's bowling team is one round away from breaking the league record for most points scored in a season. The old record is an average score per player of 287 per round. Each team has 4 players and there are 10 rounds in the season. Through the first 9 rounds, his team has scored a total of 10,440. How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. It took him 20 minutes to finish tasks from biology and two times more time to finish history. Geography took him the most time, three times more than history. How much time did Max spend on doing his homework?<n>Answer: 180<n><n>Input: Sophia ate 1/6 of her pie and she put the rest on the fridge. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:If I have to keep track of how much oxygen there is, where am I? Choices:  A: air B: water C: earth D: space shuttle E: tunnel<n><n>### Response:		<n>* if we are on earth means we have to breathe oxygen  to survive<n>* Earth has seven main layers<n>* There is the atmosphere<n>* The atmosphere is made up of: hydrogen, helium, nitrogen and oxygen<n><n>A: air<n><n>### Input If I have to keep track who is the biggest mammoth, what is my next action? Choices A: Get my notebook; B: Study their tracks; C: Catch them; D: Ask some friends; E: Find out their weight<n><n>### Response<n><n>*  We need to research and study what animals were once there and maybe we can use that for science.<n>* We can look at things that have been discovered by scientists to give information about the mammoths and all the other animals of the past.<n>* we don't just need to focus on the mammoths but on any kind of animals and the way scientists discovered this information.<n>* we can ask a scientist about a dinosaur that existed on earth.<n>* we can also talk to scientists about what tools and knowledge helped to discover that past information<n>A: Ask some friends<n><n>### Input<n><n>The world is round what is the next question I would want to know<n><n>### Response (write the question as a question):Does the moon rotate or revolve around the earth?<n><n>### Instructions<n>The teacher gave a bag of candy and said to only the boy and the girl if they will each take a piece of candy. If there candy total is more than half of the bag then they have more than half<n><n>### Instuctions<n>The teacher gave the girl and boy the following situation the girl is more than half of total the girls half of the total is three hundred of the total is also two hundred<n>the boy is two hundred seventy five the girl is six hundred eighty five how much is the next total<n><n>### Request<n><n>The next total is 910<n><n>### Constructors<n><n>(Ask for the total number of candy)<n><n>### Input <n><n>The total of the candy was ten hundred the girl ate seven hundred and fifteen the boy ate thirty five the remain of the candy is four hundred and fifty how much did the girl and the boy have left?<n><n>### Constructor<n>

Choices:  A: slender B: free flowing C: sparse D: unacquainted E: diet<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>If he or she is slender, he or she will be thin. We can see that thin people are free flowing in the way that they move around.<n><n>### Output:<n><n>A or D<n><n>### Inputs:<n><n>A: 2 B: 15<n><n>### Outputs:<n><n>A<n><n>### Details:<n><n>* Summary of the Problem:<n><n>We can see that each of the inputs, which are 15 and 2, are not equal. However the input and output are both equal to 15.<n><n>* Explanation of Answer:<n><n>From the number line, we can see that the minimum input is 1 and the range is ten. The corresponding output that is 15 is in the range of ten.<n><n>### Input<n>What is the median when an input of 1 and and input of 15 are given values?<n>* Summary of Question<n><n>The sum of the input values (15+2) is the output, which is 17.<n><n><n>### Output<n> What is the median when an output of 15 and an output of 17 are given?<n><n>### Details<n>We know that the input values are 1 and 2, so we can conclude that we need to find the median that the input values will produce. From the number line we see 3 as the output between the input values of 1 and 2. However since the input values in the question is 2 and 15, the output between the input must be 2 and 17. This means that the median is 17.5. <n><n>### Input <n><n>What is the median (the middle number) of the set of numbers when the sum of the input values is 15 and the median when the sum of the outputs are the same is 26?<n><n>### Output <n><n>What is 26? Is it a number?<n><n>### Input and Output<n><n>| Input | Output |<n>| :---: | :---: |<n>| 2 | 17 |<n>| 15 | 26 |<n><n>

Each process is performed independently on a particular tree section, which is removed from the tree immediately after completion of the process. The pencil is made up of 13 different sections of wood. The first process removes a cylindrical piece of wood from the tree, while the second process removes a square and rectangular piece of wood, each 4x4x5. It is not necessary that the exact same section of wood is chosen to perform a subsequent process. After the third process completes, in what order should the removed pieces of wood be in order to make a pencil? Enter the order from left to right in order of removal using a comma (',') between each section, with the first section being the first column.<n><n>Answer: Tree, Square, Cylinder, Rectangle<n><n>### Input  - Part IV:If we have 40 students in a class and the average height of the first 10 students is 120 centimeters and the average height of last 10 students is twice the number of the first 1-10 students' average height, what is the average student's height? How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:The master control for the Tardis is where in the main room? Choices:  A: nuclear power plant B: center C: basement D: main office E: bowel of the ship<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>E<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Write two paragraphs that will explain the answers. Please give any hints or clues that the correct answer needed.<n><n>### 1/What are the rules/preference and how did you come to that decision?<n><n>Rule = If there is more than one choice, all choices must be used.<n><n>Preference = A, C, D, B, C(main office),<n><n>### 2/What is the evidence that the answer is correct? In other words, where do you get your data from?<n><n>Cause and Effect -<n>Evidence - In the diagram, if the room to be is any other than E, the TARDIS will blow up.<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>1. B is false, in the diagram it is in the center.<n>2. It is wrong because it is the main room.<n><n>Question:<n><n><img src='assets/img/img_02.PNG'><n><n>### 3/Is the answer the only one that fits the rules and also evidence?<n><n>Yes, it is the other answers don't follow the evidence<n><n>### Question:<n><n><img height="300" src='assets/img-question-01.PNG'><n>

Beans are healthier for you<n><n>### Response:"Chicken is healthier for me" is the sentence that accurately follows the information given in the paragraph.<n><n>### Explicaiton:The paragraph clearly says that eggs are healthier than chicken, therefore the sentence "Chicken is healthier to me" follows it<n><n>### Input:#48 #193.5 #45 #24.3 #110.5 #35 #21 What is the total sum of all of these numbers?<n><n>### Response:(90 + (193.5 - 24.1) - (110.5 - 35) + 21) = 90 + 164.4 - 75.5+ 21 = 340.2<n><n>### Explication:The answer is 340.1<n><n>### Input:(0.5 * 1/2) + 3/4 * 1/3/2 =?<n><n>### Response:--<n><n>### Explicateation:You can not just put addition or subtraction on top of all your values you have to convert a part of them into numbers you are allowed to do so and divide, multiply or add, which makes it impossible to add the first and the first one.<n><n>#### What two fractions above 3/4 are equivalent?<n><n>### Explicaition:The second one is equivalent<n><n>### Input:% = 3% = 6% = 9%<n><n>### Response:-<n><n>#### What is the sum of these fractions?<n><n>### Input:) 5x - 3y + -2y 4y + 4x - 3x + 3y - 2<n><n>### Response:@(x + y)/(4,5)<n><n>

Everyone is assigned a number from 1 to 6, but not necessarily in order. Each person faces a different direction, but not one of the same directions. They‚Äôre not sitting in the same order either. If the number of each person is called out, from left to right and beginning at No. 1, then their positions are not the same as the order each person is sitting in. What‚Äôs the code that is used to identify each person? The directions of each person are in order.<n><n>## Task<n><n>## Task:<n>Write two correct statements to complete the sentence. If the pie left in the fridge weighs 1200 grams, how many grams did Sophia eat?<n>Answer: 240<n><n>Input: Sarah, Mary, and Tuan decided to go to the restaurant for a meal. They decided to split the cost of the meal evenly. If the total price of the meal comes to $67 and they have a coupon for $4, how much does each person need to contribute to the bill?<n>Answer: 21<n><n>Input: Tom's brother is 4 times as old as Tom's dog. If in 6 years, Tom's brother will be 30 years, how old is Tom's dog going to be in six years?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:How can an artist commemorate a horse forever. Choices:  A: hoof B: kentucky derby C: race track D: painting E: triple crown<n><n>### Response:		(A) hoof<n><n>### Inputs:2+3=5 2+4=6 3+4=7 2+4=10 2+3=14 2+6+4+6=26<n><n>### Response (E):26<n><n>## Task<n>### For each input, write a response that matches the task.<n><n>### Input 1:3 of Mark's best friends are getting ready for Halloween. Jenna has made a costume, and she's all set! Sarah isn't sure what her costume will be yet, but she's already bought a costume piece. Mark has made plans to dress up from 5pm to 9pm. Tom is working a shift in his job so he won't get to go out until 1am. When Jenna, Sarah, Mark and 2 more of Mark's best buddies all meet for Halloween, what time will it be?<n><n>### Input2:How many times larger is an SUV than a mini van? Choices: A: five B: ten C: five hundred D: four<n><n>### Response(B) ten<n>### Inputs:(X-Y)>(X+Y)<n>```<n>1+1>=2 || true<n>2+2>=4 || false<n>3+3>=5 || false<n>5+3>=8 || true<n>```<n>### Task:(X-Y)><n>```<n>True ||(X-Y) is larger than (X+Y) which means X-Y is true<n>```<n>## Input:Bella and Betsy had 88 pieces of candy between the two of them.  They decided to split it evenly.  If Bella has 25 more pieces than Betsy, how many pieces of candy does Betsy have?<n><n>### Response:(90-25)=<n>```<n>75-25 =75<n>```<n><n>## Input:24/1=<n><n>### Response:/<n><n>## Input:The average monthly gas expense for a car's owner is 49 gallons of gas. How many 2/10 gallon bottles does it take to fill the gas tank?<n><n>###Response:(49/2)=<n>```<n>24<n>```

How many points less than the current league record per game average is the minimum average they need to score, per player, in the final round to tie the league record?<n>Answer: 27<n><n>Input: Max was doing homework in three different subjects.
